headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Marathon Petroleum Corporation Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the cal
componenttext: Welcome to the Marathon Petroleum Corporation Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Ms. Pam Beall. Ms. Beall, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandra. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's third quarter 2011 earnings webcast and conference call. You will find synchronized slides that accompany this call on our website marathonpetroleum.com. On the ca
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandra. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's third quarter 2011 earnings webcast and conference call. You will find synchronized slides that accompany this call on our website marathonpetroleum.com. On the call today are Gary Heminger, President and Chief Executive Officer; Garry Peiffer, Executive Vice President of Corporate Planning and Investor Government Relations; Don Templin, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Mike Palmer, Senior Vice President of Supply, Distribution and Planning.
On Slide 2, you'll see it contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our remarks and answers to questions today will contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. In accordance with the safe harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, Marathon Petroleum Corporation has included in its Form 10 filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and earnings release issued earlier today cautionary language identifying important factors but not necessarily all factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements. Please note that in the appendix to this presentation is other data that you may find useful. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Gary Heminger for his opening remarks.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam, and good morning to everyone. We had a very strong third quarter with $1.1 billion of net income, which is close to a record for our company. We executed on our ability to capture several of the key market drivers in our business, includin
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam, and good morning to everyone. We had a very strong third quarter with $1.1 billion of net income, which is close to a record for our company. We executed on our ability to capture several of the key market drivers in our business, including the crack spreads in our geographic markets, the differential between our sweet and sour crude basket and the spread between West Texas Intermediate price crudes and other light sweet crudes such as Light Louisiana Sweet.
I'm going to ask Mike Palmer, our Senior VP of Supply, Distribution and Planning to go into a little more detail about the crudes we process and how we are positioned to optimize the crude slate across our refineries to produce the highest value of finished product yields. But first, I want to explain our balanced approach to business.
Clearly, the WTI LLS spread is attractive today, and our earnings benefited from this market condition. We've been successful in this business a long time and we have structured our logistical and refining assets so that our future earnings and cash flow are not writing just on the wide WTI LLS spread. Market conditions are always changing, and the current price differential between WTI and LLS won't be an exception. But having said that, we believe we are well positioned to continue to benefit from the growth of crude production, and we are investing in our logistics system to ensure we have access to the growing sources of crudes that are priced off of WTI as well as Canadian crudes.
Now I would like to elaborate on what I mean by a balanced approach to our business. First, we have a balanced crude slate, refining nearly 50% sour and 50% sweet crude. We have the flexibility to alter our sweet and sour crude slate in every given quarter or in response to market conditions. Second, we are balancing our geographic markets with a little over 50% of our refining capacity in PADD II. This PADD II capacity is well positioned to refine increased Canadian crude production as well as a prospective crude production. We also have the advantage of being able to move WTI feedstocks to our logistics system to our PADD II refineries. 
Further strengthening our PADD II position, upgrades to our Detroit refinery were approximately 73% complete as of September 30, 2011. This project remains on budget and on schedule for completion in the second half of 2012. And when completed, these upgrades should allow us to process an incremental 80,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadian crude, reducing our feedstock cost and increasing Detroit's crude oil refining capacity about 15% to 120,000 barrels per day.
It is also important to note that PADD II is a net short of refined products. So we tend to run our plants at relatively higher utilization rates and better crack spreads than PADD III refineries. The other half of our crude report refining capacities in the U.S. Gulf Coast, which gives us access to favorable export markets. Our Garyville refinery is the newest and we believe one of the most efficient refineries in the country. And when we planned the expansion of Garyville, which we completed in 2009, we expected distillate demand to grow faster than gasoline demand, and that certainly has been the case. Global demand for distillate continues to increase providing the opportunity to increase distillate exports to higher valuable global markets. 
During the third quarter, we continued the optimization of Garyville, which is running significantly above its nameplate capacity. We also increased the amount of distillate for export from Garyville to approximately 73,000 barrels per day last quarter. With modest additional investment, we believe we can increase our distillate for sales exports even more, providing us with additional options to place more of our refinery production in higher value markets.
Another point of balance in our business is our integrated approach in using our significant logistics operations to connect our refineries with domestic refined product markets and with our speedway retail, Marathon brand marketing operations. Our speedway retail demand, Marathon brand marketing and other wholesale arrangements provide an assured domestic outlet for approximately 60% of our refinery gasoline production. Our speedway retail business is taking the other business we intend to grow through the combination of greenfield sites and selective acquisitions. For example, the 23 convenience stores in Chicago, Illinois and Northwest Indiana purchased by Speedway during the second quarter of 2011 continued to perform very well, and we continue to look for similar acquisition opportunities.
To quickly recap, we are balanced geographically. About 50% of our Refining and Marketing business is in the attractive PADD II market with access to growing inland crude production that could benefit our Canton, Ohio and Catlettsburg, Kentucky refineries. The other half of our refining capacity is in the Gulf Coast, with exposure to attractive export markets. We have a balanced crude slate with flexibility to process price advantaged crudes throughout our entire refining system. We have a significant margin enhancement project in our refinery to increase our ability to process even more heavy Canadian crude.
And finally, we have diverse sources of earnings and cash flow from our Pipeline Transportation and Speedway retail businesses that have been less cyclical than refining.
Before I turn it over to Mike Palmer, I want to address a question on the minds of many of our investors. What are we going to do with the cash on our balance sheet and the free cash we expect to generate in the future? We gave part of that answer on October 26 when our board approved a 25% increase in our quarterly dividend. We are committed to a balanced approach between disciplined investment in the business and returning capital to shareholders in the most appropriate form, given the many different considerations that will exist over time.
We have taken nothing off the table as we evaluated return of capital to our shareholders. However, it is important to understand our ability to issue or retire equity is not solely within our control. The spinoff of MPC from Marathon Oil was a tax-free transaction and we agreed with Marathon Oil for a period of 2 years generally not to issue or repurchase stock without their consent. We also note that the world can change very quickly. Not long ago there was very limited liquidity in the market. Given limitations in our ability to use equity over the next 2 years, we will be disciplined as we evaluate all uses of cash from investment and return of capital to shareholders. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mike Palmer to discuss our feedstock flexibility.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. One of our major objectives every day is to optimize our crude slates. We purchased those crude oils that will deliver the highest profitability through a combination of price, transportation costs and finished product yield value. We have d
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. One of our major objectives every day is to optimize our crude slates. We purchased those crude oils that will deliver the highest profitability through a combination of price, transportation costs and finished product yield value. We have developed the flexibility in terms of our logistics system, our contract mix and our business process to achieve this objective.
We have a logistics system that provides access to Canadian crude from the North, Mid-Continent crude from the West, crude production from the U.S. Gulf Coast and waterborne crude from virtually anywhere in the world through LOOP, the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port. With volatile crude oil spread, logistics flexibility is one of the keys to long-term success in this business.
During the third quarter, we continued to benefit from wider differentials between West Texas Intermediate and other light sweet crudes such as Light Louisiana Sweet, and between sweet and sour crudes. Approximately 50% of the crude we processed last quarter was sour. Leveraging our logistics systems, we were able to increase our throughput of Canadian heavy and crude price off WTI to about 38%, up approximately 35% in the second quarter and 33% in the first quarter.
WTI priced crudes represented 27% of the crude we refined during the third quarter of 2011, up from 21% in the same quarter last year. An example of what we are doing to utilize more WTI-linked crude would be our efforts at the Canton refinery to purchase Utica shale oil. We have installed a temporary truck rack that gives us the immediate ability to receive up to 1,000 barrels per day of this new production. We have engineering under way to install a permanent truck unloading facility with capacity up to 12,000 barrels per day by early next year. We are studying other options to significantly increase our overall system logistics capability as production in the Utica ramps up.
We are currently seeing very attractively priced Canadian sweet synthetic crude oil that fits our Midwest system very well. We have been utilizing the Keystone pipeline to Patoka to take advantage of this opportunity and expect it to continue through the fourth quarter and into next year. We expect U.S. inland crude production in large part due to shale plays such as the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and Utica and Canadian production to continue to show significant growth. As a result of this growth, we expect differentials for these crude oils to be favorable well into the foreseeable future. We will continue to debottleneck and enhance our logistics to allow us to take advantage of this growth. 
Don Templin will now go over the results for the quarter.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Slide 5 provides net income both on an absolute and per share basis. Our third quarter 2011 net income of $1.1 billion reflects an $856 million increase from the $277 million earned in the third quarter of 2010. Earnings per share was $3.16
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Slide 5 provides net income both on an absolute and per share basis. Our third quarter 2011 net income of $1.1 billion reflects an $856 million increase from the $277 million earned in the third quarter of 2010. Earnings per share was $3.16 for the third quarter compared to $0.77 during the same period last year. 
The waterfall chart on Slide 6 shows by segment the change in net income from the third quarter of 2010 to the third quarter of 2011. The primary reason for the increase in our net income was the increase in Refining and Marketing segment income, partially offset by higher income taxes. For the 2011 third quarter, our effective income tax rate was 35% compared with 37% in the third quarter of 2010. The 2011 tax rate was favorably impacted by an increase in the amount of income qualifying for the domestic manufacturing deduction.
I also wanted to explain the $51 million in other items. This variance primarily relates to costs associated with being a stand-alone company, including some onetime transition cost, as well as higher incentive compensation due to our strong results in 2011 and the interest expense on our $3 billion in senior notes. 
As shown on Slide 7, Refining and Marketing segment income from operations was $1.7 billion in the third quarter of 2011 compared to $352 million in the third quarter of 2010. The increase was primarily the result of a higher Refining and Marketing gross margin, which I will discuss on the next slide.
Slide 8 shows a few of the economic drivers contributing to the improved Refining and Marketing gross margin for the third quarter. Our gross margin in the third quarter of 2011 benefited from a wider sweet sour differential, higher Chicago and U.S. Gulf Coast crack spreads and a wider WTI LLS differential. The sweet sour differential increased approximately 48% from an average of $8.08 per barrel in the third quarter 2011 to $11.94 per barrel in the third quarter of '11. The benchmark for our blended Chicago U.S. Gulf Coast LLS crack spread increased from $2.83 per barrel in the third quarter of 2010 to $5.98 per barrel in the third quarter of 2011.
In addition, the WTI LLS differential averaged $22.92 per barrel in the third quarter of 2011. This was an increase of $19.49 per barrel compared to an average of $3.43 per barrel in the third quarter 2010.
Not reflected in these industry metrics are a number of other factors that impact our gross margin, such as differences between the spot price of refined products used in the crack spread calculation and our actual sales price. In addition, our average refinery inputs were 1,368,000  barrels per day during the 2011 third quarter compared with 1,445,000 barrels per day during the same quarter last year. The 77,000-barrel per day decline from the third quarter last year primarily reflects the impact of the sale of our Minnesota refinery in December 2010.
Speedway's income from operations was $85 million in the third quarter of 2011 compared with $105 million in the third quarter of 2010. The $20 million decline in income from operations is almost entirely attributable to the absence of the 166 convenience stores that were part of the December 2010 sale of our Minnesota refinery and related assets. 
On a same-store basis, gasoline sales decreased 2% and merchandise sales increased 2% in the third quarter of 2011 compared with the same quarter of last year. The lower same-store gasoline sales primarily reflect the impact of the higher price level of gasoline. Speedway's average retail gasoline price was $3.52 per gallon during the third quarter of 2011 compared with $2.64 per gallon last year. Same-store gasoline sales volumes in October 2011 are up slightly to the comparable period last year.
Slide 10 shows changes in our Pipeline Transportation segment income. Income from operations was $56 million in the third quarter of 2011 compared with $39 million in the third quarter of 2010. This improvement is primarily attributable to the absence of nonroutine maintenance and impairment expenses incurred in 2010, partially offset by less equity affiliate income in the 2011 third quarter.
The chart on Slide 11 provides an analysis of cash flows for the third quarter of 2011. At September 30, 2011, our cash balance was just under $3 billion. Operating cash flow before changes in working capital was nearly $1.5 billion. The working capital benefit of $238 million noted on this slide primarily relates to decreases in accounts receivable and inventory and increases in our payables since June 30. Capital expenditures and investments during the quarter were $317 million, primarily related to our Detroit heavy oil refinery project.
The first federal income tax return we will file as a separate company will be for a short 6-month tax year. Federal income tax rules allow us to make an initial estimated tax payment on December 15 rather than making payments in each of the quarters. As a result, our cash flows for the third quarter of 2011 did not include any estimated federal income tax payments. The company currently projects its December 15 estimated federal tax payment will include the liability of between $400 million and $500 million related to the third quarter earnings. We expect capital spending for the full year 2011 will be approximately $1.4 billion, including approximately $158 million of capitalized interest and corporate items.
Slide 12 shows that at the end of the third quarter, we had over $2.9 billion of cash and approximately $3.3 billion of debt. Our cash adjusted debt-to-capital ratio was 3%. Along with our $2.9 billion in cash, we have an undrawn $2 billion revolving credit facility and an undrawn $1 billion trade receivable securitization facility. This should provide us with significant flexibility to manage our operations and to pursue value-enhancing bottom line growth opportunities. As we look forward, we expect our refining crude oil inputs to be approximately 1.2 million barrels per day for the fourth quarter of 2011.
While it is hard to predict what will happen to crack spreads and differentials for the remainder of the year, I wanted to provide an update on what we have seen in the market during the month of October. The Chicago and Gulf Coast LLS 6-3-2-1 crack spreads have decreased in October compared to the third quarter. The preliminary crack spreads are $2.15 and $2.48 for October, for Chicago and Gulf Coast, respectively. The sweet sour differential averaged $5.46 in October, and the WTI LLS differential averaged $25.65. As you know, our historical increase in corporate cost do not reflect all of the cost of operating as a stand-alone company. We estimate these costs will total an incremental $80 million pretax on a normalized annualized basis. Finally, assuming no special items during the fourth quarter of 2011, we expect the overall effective income tax rate to be approximately 37% for the full year.
Now I will turn the call over to back to Pam Beall.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Don. Before we open the call to questions, I just want to remind you that our first Investor Day will take place on November 30 in New York City. Management presentations will begin at 8:30 a.m. If you've not registered for the meeting and wish
componenttext: Thank you, Don. Before we open the call to questions, I just want to remind you that our first Investor Day will take place on November 30 in New York City. Management presentations will begin at 8:30 a.m. If you've not registered for the meeting and wish to attend in person, you can contact Beth Hunter or me. For those unable to attend in person, there will be an audio webcast of the management presentation. As we open the call for questions, we ask that to accommodate all who wish to ask questions, you limit yourself to one question plus a follow-up. You may reprompt for additional questions if time permits. And with that, Sandra, we'd now like to open the call to questions.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: Just a question for Mike I guess at the beginning. So when I'm thinking about your refineries, Patoka, you'll be able to access a bit more crude. As XL is built, you can capture more Eagle Ford. You've got Utica coming and extra Canadian at. Is there anything else that we should be thinking about in terms of your ability to capture quick discounts?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Ed, I think you've hit on most of them. I think that we continue to focus on North America and we look at the Canada and the Canadian growth to continue. We think that's going to be a real benefit to our Midwest system and then the shale plays. In a
componenttext: Well, Ed, I think you've hit on most of them. I think that we continue to focus on North America and we look at the Canada and the Canadian growth to continue. We think that's going to be a real benefit to our Midwest system and then the shale plays. In addition to the shale plays, I think that there is other production going on. One of the things I mentioned in my talk was the sweet synthetic. We certainly see the sweet synthetic production being robust in December forward and we've already begun purchasing more of that crude. The differentials versus LLS are still very attractive. So, Ed, I think that pretty much sums it up.

componenttext: Gary, you made some comments about return of cash and seem to be saying that you can't buy back stock without permission, without agreement from Marathon Oil. Is that also something that would trigger a change in the tax of the spin?

componenttext: Sure, Paul. I mean the tax sharing agreement that was put into place was to protect the tax-free status of the spin. So those protections -- and Marathon Oil Company is the obligor, the tax obligor. So those protections were put in there or those stipulations are put in there so that Marathon Oil Company could weigh in on those conversations. There are opportunities, I guess, that you could have some shared transactions but we've not explored that with them currently.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: So for all intents and purposes, you won't be buying back or issuing stock in the next 2 years?
componenttext: So for all intents and purposes, you won't be buying back or issuing stock in the next 2 years?

componenttext: As we said today, Paul, that would be our plan.

componenttext: So that would limit you then to I guess special dividends sitting on cash?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Or investment opportunities that we may have. So definitely, our base dividend, we could consider a special dividend. And as I said, we're going to be very disciplined in our capital spend. We've already spoken to the investment we made in northwestern In
componenttext: Or investment opportunities that we may have. So definitely, our base dividend, we could consider a special dividend. And as I said, we're going to be very disciplined in our capital spend. We've already spoken to the investment we made in northwestern Indiana and Chicago with some retail facilities, but again, we want to have a bulletproof balance sheet as we go into this business, and we all understand what happened in '08 and '09 and liquidity in the markets and balance sheet of some and how dividends have moved over that period of time. So we're going to be very careful. But you are correct. We don't plan on issuing nor buying back any equity in the short term.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, we review this every board meeting. So just depend on where we are at the time. As Don mentioned, I think some questions that we have received earlier this morning on cash, I think, and Don explained it well in his presentation here that our Federal
componenttext: Yes, we review this every board meeting. So just depend on where we are at the time. As Don mentioned, I think some questions that we have received earlier this morning on cash, I think, and Don explained it well in his presentation here that our Federal tax payment is not going to be made until December 15 or so. So I think that was a surprise to some people that they didn't know that we didn't make that tax payment here in Q3. So that answers a little bit of the cash. But still at the end of the day, we're setting on a very strong position, and we will look at it as I say at every board meeting.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttextpreview: Right. And there's an array of and we don't have enough time to go to all the detail and what I mean by that. Basically, what my meaning is I go back when we first started talking about this spin in 2008 and then the liquidity in the market completely dri
componenttext: Right. And there's an array of and we don't have enough time to go to all the detail and what I mean by that. Basically, what my meaning is I go back when we first started talking about this spin in 2008 and then the liquidity in the market completely dried up. We don't want to be in that position and we don't want to have to manage from that type of a position. So we will go slow. We'll be very disciplined in our investment and then we will work with the board on how we look at our dividends.

componenttextpreview: Gary, can you give us an update on the diesel export expansion timing? And what are the capacity you're looking for on exports?
componenttext: Gary, can you give us an update on the diesel export expansion timing? And what are the capacity you're looking for on exports?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in fact, we've already started. Some of this is what we call debottleneck work where you put in some additional lines to adopt or you put in -- you can tie in some additional to a manifold in order to be able to get more product or to load faster at
componenttext: Well, in fact, we've already started. Some of this is what we call debottleneck work where you put in some additional lines to adopt or you put in -- you can tie in some additional to a manifold in order to be able to get more product or to load faster at an export facility. So say we've already started to somehow the engineering of complete on a couple of these projects. We did not have the detail yet on the amount of export, but I would say, Chi, it's kind of mid-2012 is when we would expect to have some additional capacity and it's all at Garyville. It's what we're looking at right now. So it will come in stages. First, it will be some debottlenecking of some of the lines and some our pumping capacity; and second, we'll look at maybe another tank in order to provide us somewhat additional optionality.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the way we're kind of looking at things, Chi, and it's a very good question, but throughout the entire Q3, we've had the problems in Europe and it continues to grow. There've been some European refineries that have some offsets, but more so offsets
componenttext: Well, the way we're kind of looking at things, Chi, and it's a very good question, but throughout the entire Q3, we've had the problems in Europe and it continues to grow. There've been some European refineries that have some offsets, but more so offsets in Latin America type refineries. So the global diesel demand continues to increase. But I think we're seeing is that maybe logistics are continuing to balance out different markets and move distillate that prior was either going into Europe or maybe Europe was moving a little bit more towards the -- and some of their refinery is that logistics is changing some of those patterns. And if anything, we're continuing to see it increase and we continue to see more robust response to the export volumes that we have available each week.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then, finally, just a couple of housekeeping things. Looks like G&A expenses were up quarter-over-quarter in 3Q. Do you have any guidance on that and going forward? And then did you have any derivative gains in the refining results
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then, finally, just a couple of housekeeping things. Looks like G&A expenses were up quarter-over-quarter in 3Q. Do you have any guidance on that and going forward? And then did you have any derivative gains in the refining results in the quarter?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chi, this is Don. Let me answer this second question. We did have -- consistent with prior quarters, we did have derivative activity and we had a $258 million gain in this quarter. And then with respect to your question on G&A, we're estimating as a stand
componenttext: Chi, this is Don. Let me answer this second question. We did have -- consistent with prior quarters, we did have derivative activity and we had a $258 million gain in this quarter. And then with respect to your question on G&A, we're estimating as a stand-alone company that we will have incremental costs of roughly $80 million on a normalized basis per year, yes, annually, per year. The SG&A item, one of the contributors to that was about $15 million of cost related to credit card fees in there. There's an offset in revenues. So some of that increase this quarter was just a function of our brand marketing credit card fees and increase in the price of product.

Still seem to get favorable comments out of the administration, but I don't know how long this issue in Nebraska may delay things.

And we think we can do it with relatively low investment.

componenttext: This is Garry Peiffer. Now I think you've hit the major point as we shown on Page 8 of the slide deck that we just reviewed, and this is not much different than what we talked about in the past. The biggest difference versus the past, obviously, is the WTI LLS is now a few dollars like we showed back in the last year. It's now obviously, in the third quarter of '11. It was $23. So when you add up 50% of the sweet sour differential, and I might note on that schedule on that slide, we define it based upon what we would expect to run on an annualized basis of different types of crudes. That changes quarter-to-quarter and it changes by how individual companies tend to calculate that number. And then the other big thing for us, obviously, is the crack spread for the U.S. Gulf Coast and Chicago. So you've hit the major point but the big one now and we kind of laid out in that table to help a little bit is WTI were running, that also had a big impact versus LLS this quarter.

componenttext: Well, I wouldn't go so far as to say that our billing forward is your that we may be considering that. headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel, I can clarify that. As you know, the Keystone frontline was completed mid-2010. And it takes time to kind of debottleneck both at the origin point as well as destination when you get into the trunk line like that put into place. So we've been
componenttext: Yes, Faisel, I can clarify that. As you know, the Keystone frontline was completed mid-2010. And it takes time to kind of debottleneck both at the origin point as well as destination when you get into the trunk line like that put into place. So we've been continually doing that month-to-month. So our objective continues to be to bring in as much Canadian crude as economically makes sense for us. And there are various things that we're doing to enable that to happen, and that'll continue in the future.

componenttext: Faisel, I'm glad you brought that question up because I want to reiterate and that's a point for me going into how balanced we are. And as all the numbers have proved, we are very balanced across the system and we have visibility to bring in further Canadian, bring in WTI-based crudes or obviously, export crudes that could commence for hit Garyville or our Midwest system. So that's really the point we're trying to make to everyone.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary just a follow-up on your thoughts on things like Brent TI and LLS TI. You are, obviously, more of a PADD II Midwest refining company. Do you see any distinction between PADD II and PADD IV in terms of how spreads might progress? And I guess I'm reall
componenttext: Gary just a follow-up on your thoughts on things like Brent TI and LLS TI. You are, obviously, more of a PADD II Midwest refining company. Do you see any distinction between PADD II and PADD IV in terms of how spreads might progress? And I guess I'm really thinking about the period before things like Keystone XL and some of the other pipelines come on. In the period before that, do you see any reason why being in the Midwest refiner the spreads could close on you faster than the folks in the Rockies?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Mike?
componenttext: Well, Mike?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arjun, I don't see why that would happen. Now I think that it will happen for the entire market at once.
componenttext: Yes, Arjun, I don't see why that would happen. Now I think that it will happen for the entire market at once.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: And in terms of your pipeline business and the ability so I guess both continue to access some of the discounted crudes as well as participate in some of the growth rate, do you see your pipeline business something you'd also like to expand? You mentioned
componenttext: And in terms of your pipeline business and the ability so I guess both continue to access some of the discounted crudes as well as participate in some of the growth rate, do you see your pipeline business something you'd also like to expand? You mentioned the retail. But whether it's see ways on the market does a lot of other proposed projects, do you see MPC participate in some of that or not?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, that big new play, which is in the heart of our pipeline system will be probably more of a gathering system type play than a frontline. The majority of our pipeline systems today are trunk line. But obviously, the Utica, being right here in our back
componenttext: Well, that big new play, which is in the heart of our pipeline system will be probably more of a gathering system type play than a frontline. The majority of our pipeline systems today are trunk line. But obviously, the Utica, being right here in our backyard, could have some opportunity around a gathering and distributing or transporting from a lease custody transfer type point. Back to your question on PADD IV versus PADD II and I really think about how to pipelines move. Today, all of PAD IV is saturated with the amount of crude that goes directly to the refineries and the majority of that is going to go either by either gathering system or truck. So I definitely agree with Mike that the systems as you export and all those systems again will move west to east or a little bit south and then to the east that I believe that they will go hand in hand because all of those refineries today will be completely full with those type of production is coming out of the Canada, the Bakken, the Niobrara and some of those areas.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's really helpful. And just a final one, and I apologize if I may partly repeat a previous question, but when you do a tax-free spin, I'd get why someone else couldn't buy MPC without potentially having some tax liabilities, and I think I get the stoc
componenttext: That's really helpful. And just a final one, and I apologize if I may partly repeat a previous question, but when you do a tax-free spin, I'd get why someone else couldn't buy MPC without potentially having some tax liabilities, and I think I get the stock buyback part of it. What I wasn't quite clear on is if you saw something you wanted to buy, are you saying you couldn't equity for that? Or more you'd have to consult with Marathon Oil and they'd have to sign off on it, if you will? Are you actually prohibited from issuing equity to buy something?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: We believe we are prohibited from doing that without their permission.
componenttext: We believe we are prohibited from doing that without their permission.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Without their permission. But that doesn't mean you would necessarily incur a large tax liability if you did something. Again, I get the take-out situation where it likely would trigger a tax event. But if it's just a question of asking for their permissi
componenttext: Without their permission. But that doesn't mean you would necessarily incur a large tax liability if you did something. Again, I get the take-out situation where it likely would trigger a tax event. But if it's just a question of asking for their permission or do you actually think MRO and MPC would actually incur a tax liability by one of you issuing equity?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean when we went to seek or when they went with Marathon Oil Company to seek the tax-free, the private letter ruling, we agreed that we wouldn't do that. So that is the stipulation in that agreement.
componenttext: Well, I mean when we went to seek or when they went with Marathon Oil Company to seek the tax-free, the private letter ruling, we agreed that we wouldn't do that. So that is the stipulation in that agreement.

componenttextpreview: I understand.
componenttext: I understand.

componenttext: The next question is from Blake Fernandez from Howard Weil.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: I want to dig into the WTI-linked crude. You've illustrated that you moved it up from 33% to 35% and now 38%. Do you have a sense of where that number could go to?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Blake, as I said earlier, we have a number of other debottleneck type projects that we're working through right now. And, of course,, the bottom line part of the answer is going to be how much crude is available of those types of crudes to get into
componenttext: Well, Blake, as I said earlier, we have a number of other debottleneck type projects that we're working through right now. And, of course,, the bottom line part of the answer is going to be how much crude is available of those types of crudes to get into the big trunk lines and then service PADD II. But we will outline in more detail and I'm not being evasive of the question today. Just I think everybody understands as you put different transactions together to be able to give you that opportunity, you really don't want to talk about them until you get everything complete. So we expect to give you more color on that at our November meeting.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Understood. Second question for you on back to the Utica and Canton. I understand you're still kind of working the TrackBacks and the ability to put some battles over there. But ultimately, is there an opportunity to actually expand Canton?
componenttext: Understood. Second question for you on back to the Utica and Canton. I understand you're still kind of working the TrackBacks and the ability to put some battles over there. But ultimately, is there an opportunity to actually expand Canton?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's way too early to determine. The thing that we will look at based on the type of crude that we're seeing upfront is a very light crude. So you could look at increasing some of the process units. Rather than increasing the crude distillation capacity,
componenttext: It's way too early to determine. The thing that we will look at based on the type of crude that we're seeing upfront is a very light crude. So you could look at increasing some of the process units. Rather than increasing the crude distillation capacity, you look at some of the downstream process units to be able to get more throughputs in some of those units, Blake. Now the thing is I'm speaking to Canton. At Catlettsburg, a very large refinery and again, depending -- I think all the 5 wells or so producing out of today something like that, and continue to do research on the different areas that are producing from today to determine what that crude could mean long term. So as Mike Palmer said, very early in the stage to determine what might be the best fit.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: The next question is from Jeff from Siemens.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Lots of questions on WTI, so let's shift to another region. When you look at crude storage inventories that fall in aggressively over the last 8 weeks, PADD II and PADD IV's great storage roughly right where it was last year. Cushion stops are down, but m
componenttext: Lots of questions on WTI, so let's shift to another region. When you look at crude storage inventories that fall in aggressively over the last 8 weeks, PADD II and PADD IV's great storage roughly right where it was last year. Cushion stops are down, but most of the decline has happened on the Gulf Coast. And with the SPR release, which you guys benefited from purchases there, it kind of depressed Gulf Coast good pricing and closed the -- for imports. During the month of August, imports remained pretty low. I guess as people shift it as best they can to Mid-Continent and cheaper feedstocks. How do you expect the Gulf Coast to play out as we move forward? Did the import stay low inventory stay low? Or do you see a change as we move through the end of the year and into 2012 there?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think -- this is Mike Palmer. Certainly, in the short-term that you're talking about, year end or just into the new year, I think that it's pretty hard for us right now to see that the market is going to change significantly. With it being close ev
componenttext: Yes, I think -- this is Mike Palmer. Certainly, in the short-term that you're talking about, year end or just into the new year, I think that it's pretty hard for us right now to see that the market is going to change significantly. With it being close even though it's common a bit in the last 10 days to 14 days, we still are not seeing very many opportunities on cargo crude that works for us. So I would not expect things to change much from where they've been in the last few months.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: Welcome to the Marathon Petroleum Corporation Third Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sandra, and I will be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Ms. Pam Beall. Ms. Beall, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandra. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's third quarter 2011 earnings webcast and conference call. You'll find synchronized slides that accompany this call on our website, marathonpetroleum.com. On the cal
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandra. Good morning, everybody, and welcome to Marathon Petroleum Corporation's third quarter 2011 earnings webcast and conference call. You'll find synchronized slides that accompany this call on our website, marathonpetroleum.com. On the call today are Gary Heminger, President and Chief Executive Officer; Garry Peiffer, Executive Vice President of Corporate Planning and Investor and Government Relations; Don Templin, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Mike Palmer, Senior Vice President of Supply, Distribution and Planning.
On Slide 2, you'll see it contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our remarks and answers to questions today will contain forward-looking statements subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. In accordance with the safe harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, Marathon Petroleum Corporation has included in its Form 10 filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and earnings release issued earlier today cautionary language identifying important factors, but not necessarily all factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements. Please note that in the appendix to this presentation is other data that you may find useful. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Gary Hemminger for his opening remarks.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam, and good morning to everyone. We had a very strong third quarter with $1.1 billion of net income, which is close to a record for our company. We executed on our ability to capture several of the key market drivers in our business, includin
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam, and good morning to everyone. We had a very strong third quarter with $1.1 billion of net income, which is close to a record for our company. We executed on our ability to capture several of the key market drivers in our business, including the crack spreads in our geographic markets, the differential between our sweet and sour crude basket and the spread between West Texas Intermediate price crudes and other light sweet crudes such as Light Louisiana Sweet.
I'm going to ask Mike Palmer, our Senior VP of Supply, Distribution and Planning to go into a little more detail about the crudes we process and how we are positioned to optimize the crude slate across our refineries to produce the highest value finished product yields. But first, I want to explain our balanced approach to business.
Clearly, the WTI LLS spread is attractive today, and our earnings benefited from this market condition. We've been successful in this business a long time, and we have structured our logistical and refining assets so that our future earnings and cash flow are not riding just on the wide WTI LLS spread. Market conditions are always changing, and the current price differential between WTI and LLS won't be an exception. But having said that, we believe we are well positioned to continue to benefit from the growth of inland crude production, and we are investing in our logistics system to ensure we have access to the growing sources of crudes that are priced off of WTI, as well as Canadian crudes.
Now I would like to elaborate on what I mean by a balanced approach to our business. First, we have a balanced crude slate, refining nearly 50% sour and 50% sweet crude. We have the flexibility to alter our sweet and sour crude slate in any given quarter in response to market conditions. Second, we're balancing our geographic markets with a little over 50% of our refining capacity in PADD II. This PADD II capacity is well positioned to refine increased Canadian crude production, as well as the prospective Utica crude production. We also have the advantage of being able to move WTI feedstocks through our logistics system to our PADD II refineries. 
Further strengthening our PADD II position, upgrades to our Detroit refinery were approximately 73% complete as of September 30, 2011. This project remains on budget and on schedule for completion in the second half of 2012. And when completed, these upgrades should allow us to process an incremental 80,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadian crude, reducing our feedstock cost and increasing Detroit's crude oil refining capacity about 15% to 120,000 barrels per day.
It is also important to note that PADD II is a net short of refined products. So we tend to run our plants at relatively higher utilization rates and better crack spreads than PADD III refineries. The other half of our crude refining capacity is in the U.S. Gulf Coast, which gives us access to favorable export markets. Our Garyville refinery is the newest, and we believe one of the most efficient refineries in the country. And when we planned the expansion of Garyville, which we completed in 2009, we expected distillate demand to grow faster than gasoline demand, and that certainly has been the case. Global demand for distillate continues to increase, providing the opportunity to increase distillate exports to higher-value global markets. 
During the third quarter, we continued the optimization of Garyville, which is running significantly above its nameplate capacity. We also increased the amount of distillates sold for export from Garyville to approximately 73,000 barrels per day last quarter. With modest additional investment, we believe we can increase our distillate for sales export even more, providing us with additional options to place more of our refinery production in higher value markets.
Another point of balance in our business is our integrated approach in using our significant logistics operations to connect our refineries with domestic refined product markets and with our Speedway retail, Marathon brand marketing operations. Our Speedway retail demand, Marathon brand marketing and other wholesale arrangements provide an assured domestic outlet for approximately 60% of our refinery gasoline production. Our Speedway retail business is the segment of the business we intend to grow through a combination of greenfield sites and selective acquisitions. For example, the 23 convenience stores in Chicago, Illinois and Northwest Indiana purchased by Speedway during the second quarter of 2011 continued to perform very well, and we continue to look for similar acquisition opportunities.
To quickly recap, we are balanced geographically. About 50% of our Refining and Marketing business is in the attractive PADD II market with access to growing inland crude production that could benefit our Canton, Ohio and Catlettsburg, Kentucky refineries. The other half of our refining capacity is in the Gulf Coast, with exposure to attractive export markets. We have a balanced crude slate with a flexibility to process price-advantaged crudes throughout our entire refining system. We have a significant margin enhancement project at our Detroit refinery to increase our ability to process even more heavy Canadian crude.
And finally, we have diverse sources of earnings and cash flow from our Pipeline Transportation and Speedway retail businesses that have been less cyclical than refining.
Before I turn it over to Mike Palmer, I want to address a question on the minds of many of our investors. What are we going to do with the cash on our balance sheet and the free cash we expect to generate in the future? We gave part of that answer on October 26 when our board approved a 25% increase in our quarterly dividend. We are committed to a balanced approach between disciplined investment in the business and returning capital to shareholders in the most appropriate form, given the many different considerations that will exist over time.
We have taken nothing off the table as we evaluate return of capital to our shareholders. However, it is important to understand our ability to issue or retire equity is not solely within our control. The spinoff of MPC from Marathon Oil was a tax-free transaction, and we agreed with Marathon Oil for a period of 2 years generally not to issue or repurchase stock without their consent. We also know that the world can change very quickly. Not long ago there was very limited liquidity in the market. Given limitations in our ability to use equity over the next 2 years, we will be disciplined as we evaluate all uses of cash for investments and return of capital to shareholders. 
And now I'll turn it over to Mike Palmer to discuss our feedstock flexibility.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary. One of our major objectives every day is to optimize our crude slates. We purchased those crude oils that will deliver the highest profitability through a combination of price, transportation costs and finished product yield value. We have d
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary. One of our major objectives every day is to optimize our crude slates. We purchased those crude oils that will deliver the highest profitability through a combination of price, transportation costs and finished product yield value. We have developed the flexibility in terms of our logistics system, our contract mix and our business process to achieve this objective.
We have a logistics system that provides access to Canadian crude from the North, Mid-Continent crude from the West, crude production from the U.S. Gulf Coast and waterborne crude from virtually anywhere in the world through LOOP, the Louisiana Offshore Oil Port. With volatile crude oil spreads, logistics flexibility is one of the keys to long-term success in this business.
During the third quarter, we continue to benefit from wider differentials between West Texas Intermediate and other light sweet crudes such as Light Louisiana Sweet, and between sweet and sour crudes. Approximately 50% of the crude we processed last quarter was sour. Leveraging our logistics systems, we were able to increase our throughput of Canadian heavy and crude price off WTI to about 38%, up approximately 35% in the second quarter and 33% in the first quarter.
WTI-priced crudes represented 27% of the crude we refined during the third quarter of 2011, up from 21% in the same quarter last year. An example of what we are doing to utilize more WTI-linked crude would be our efforts at the Canton refinery to purchase Utica shale oil. We have installed a temporary truck rack that gives us the immediate ability to receive up to 1,000 barrels per day of this new production. We have engineering under way to install a permanent truck unloading facility with capacity up to 12,000 barrels per day by early next year. We are studying other options to significantly increase our overall system logistics capability as production in the Utica ramps up.
We are currently seeing very attractively priced Canadian sweet synthetic crude oil that fits our Midwest system very well. We have been utilizing the Keystone pipeline to Patoka to take advantage of this opportunity, and expect it to continue through the fourth quarter and into next year. We expect U.S. inland crude production in large part due to shale plays such as the Bakken, the Eagle Ford and Utica, and Canadian production to continue to show significant growth. As a result of this growth, we expect differentials for these crude oils to be favorable well into the foreseeable future. We will continue to debottleneck and enhance our logistics to allow us to take advantage of this growth. 
Don Templin will now go over the financial results  for the quarter.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mike. Slide 5 provides net income both on an absolute and per share basis. Our third quarter 2011 net income of $1.1 billion reflects an $856 million increase from the $277 million earned in the third quarter of 2010. Earnings per share was $3.16
componenttext:
Thanks, Mike. Slide 5 provides net income both on an absolute and per share basis. Our third quarter 2011 net income of $1.1 billion reflects an $856 million increase from the $277 million earned in the third quarter of 2010. Earnings per share was $3.16 for the third quarter compared to $0.77 during the same period last year. 
The waterfall chart on Slide 6 shows by segment the change in net income from the third quarter of 2010 to the third quarter of 2011. The primary reason for the increase in our net income was the increase in Refining and Marketing segment income, partially offset by higher income taxes. For the 2011 third quarter, our effective income tax rate was 35% compared with 37% in the third quarter of 2010. The 2011 tax rate was favorably impacted by an increase in the amount of income qualifying for the domestic manufacturing deduction.
I also wanted to explain the $51 million in other items. This variance primarily relates to costs associated with being a stand-alone company, including some onetime transition costs, as well as higher incentive compensation due to our strong results in 2011 and the interest expense on our $3 billion in senior notes. 
As shown on Slide 7, Refining and Marketing segment income from operations was $1.7 billion in the third quarter of 2011 compared to $352 million in the third quarter of 2010. The increase was primarily the result of a higher Refining and Marketing gross margin, which I will discuss on the next slide.
Slide 8 shows a few of the economic drivers contributing to the improved Refining and Marketing gross margin for the third quarter. Our gross margin in the third quarter of 2011 benefited from a wider sweet/sour differential, higher Chicago and U.S. Gulf Coast crack spreads and a wider WTI LLS differential. The sweet/sour differential increased approximately 48% from an average of $8.08 per barrel in the third quarter of 2010 to $11.94 per barrel in the third quarter of '11. The benchmark for our blended Chicago U.S. Gulf Coast LLS crack spread increased from $2.83 per barrel in the third quarter of 2010 to $5.98 per barrel in the third quarter of 2011.
In addition, the WTI LLS differential averaged $22.92 per barrel in the third quarter of 2011. This was an increase of $19.49 per barrel compared to an average of $3.43 per barrel in the third quarter of 2010.
Not reflected in these industry metrics are a number of other factors that impact our gross margin, such as differences between the spot price of refined products used in the crack spread calculation and our actual sales price. In addition, our average refinery inputs were 1,368,000  barrels per day during the 2011 third quarter, compared to 1,445,000 barrels per day during the same quarter last year. The 77,000-barrel per day decline from the third quarter last year primarily reflects the impact of the sale of our Minnesota refinery in December 2010.
Speedway's income from operations was $85 million in the third quarter of 2011, compared with $105 million in the third quarter of 2010. The $20 million decline in income from operations is almost entirely attributable to the absence of the 166 convenience stores that were part of the December 2010 sale of our Minnesota refinery and related assets. 
On a same-store basis, gasoline sales decreased 2% and merchandise sales increased 2% in the third quarter of 2011, compared with the same quarter of last year. The lower same-store gasoline sales primarily reflect the impact of the higher price level of gasoline. Speedway's average retail gasoline price was $3.52 per gallon during the third quarter of 2011, compared with $2.64 per gallon last year. Same-store gasoline sales volumes in October 2011 are up slightly to the comparable period last year.
Slide 10 shows changes in our Pipeline Transportation segment income. Income from operations was $56 million in the third quarter of 2011 compared with $39 million in the third quarter of 2010. This improvement is primarily attributable to the absence of nonroutine maintenance and impairment expenses incurred in 2010, partially offset by less equity affiliate income in the 2011 third quarter.
The chart on Slide 11 provides an analysis of cash flows for the third quarter of 2011. At September 30, 2011, our cash balance was just under $3 billion. Operating cash flow before changes in working capital was nearly $1.5 billion. The working capital benefit of $238 million noted on this slide primarily relates to decreases in accounts receivable in the inventory and increases in our payables since June 30. Capital expenditures and investments during the quarter were $317 million, primarily related to our Detroit heavy oil refinery project.
The first federal income tax return we will file as a separate company will be for a short 6-month tax year. Federal income tax rules allow us to make an initial estimated tax payment on December 15, rather than making payments in each of the quarters. As a result, our cash flows for the third quarter of 2011 did not include any estimated federal income tax payments. The company currently projects its December 15 estimated federal tax payment will include a liability of between $400 million and $500 million related to the third quarter earnings. We expect capital spending for the full year 2011 will be approximately $1.4 billion, including approximately $158 million of capitalized interest and corporate items.
Slide 12 shows that at the end of the third quarter, we had over $2.9 billion of cash and approximately $3.3 billion of debt. Our cash adjusted debt-to-capital ratio was 3%. Along with our $2.9 billion in cash, we have an undrawn $2 billion revolving credit facility and an undrawn $1 billion trade receivable securitization facility. This should provide us with significant flexibility to manage our operations and to pursue value-enhancing bottom line growth opportunities. As we look forward, we expect our refining crude oil inputs to be approximately 1.2 million barrels per day for the fourth quarter of 2011.
While it is hard to predict what will happen to crack spreads and differentials for the remainder of the year, I wanted to provide an update on what we've seen in the market during the month of October. The Chicago and Gulf Coast LLS 6-3-2-1 crack spreads have decreased in October compared to the third quarter. The preliminary crack spreads are $2.15 and $2.48 for October for Chicago and Gulf Coast, respectively. The sweet/sour differential averaged $5.46 in October, and the WTI/LLS differential averaged $25.65. As you know, our historical pre-spin corporate costs do not reflect all of the costs of operating as a standalone company. We estimate these costs will total an incremental $80 million pretax on a normalized annualized basis. Finally, assuming no special items during the fourth quarter of 2011, we expect the overall effective income tax rate to be approximately 37% for the full year.
Now I will turn the call back to Pam Beall.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: Thank you, Don. Before we open the call to questions, I just want to remind you that our first Investor Day will take place on November 30 in New York City. Management presentations will begin at 8:30 a.m. If you've not registered for the meeting and wish to attend in person, you can contact Beth Hunter or me. For those unable to attend in person, there will be an audio webcast of the management presentations. As we open the call for questions, we ask that to accommodate all who wish to ask questions, you limit yourself to one question plus a follow-up. You may reprompt for additional questions if time permits. And with that, Sandra, we'd now like to open the call to questions.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Ed, I think you've hit on most of them. I think that we continue to focus on North America and we look at the Canada and the Canadian growth to continue. We think that's going to be a real benefit to our Midwest system, and then the shale plays. In
componenttext: Well, Ed, I think you've hit on most of them. I think that we continue to focus on North America and we look at the Canada and the Canadian growth to continue. We think that's going to be a real benefit to our Midwest system, and then the shale plays. In addition to the shale plays, I think that there is other production going on. One of the things I mentioned in my talk was the sweet synthetic. We certainly see the sweet synthetic production being robust in December forward, and we've already begun purchasing more of that crude. The differentials versus LLS are still very attractive. So Ed, I think that pretty much sums it up.

componenttextpreview: Yes, we review this every board meeting, so just to plan on where we are at the time. As Don mentioned, I think some questions that we have received earlier this morning on cash, I think, and Don explained it well in his presentation here that our Federal
componenttext: Yes, we review this every board meeting, so just to plan on where we are at the time. As Don mentioned, I think some questions that we have received earlier this morning on cash, I think, and Don explained it well in his presentation here that our Federal tax payment is not going to be made until December 15 or so. So I think that was a surprise to some people that they didn't know that we didn't make that tax payment here in Q3. So that answers a little bit of the cash. But still at the end of the day, we're setting on a very strong position, and we will look at it, as I say, at every board meeting.

componenttextpreview: Right. And there's an array of -- we don't have enough time for me to go into all of the detail and what I mean by that. But basically, what my meaning is, I go back to when we first started talking about this spin in 2008, and then the liquidity in the m
componenttext: Right. And there's an array of -- we don't have enough time for me to go into all of the detail and what I mean by that. But basically, what my meaning is, I go back to when we first started talking about this spin in 2008, and then the liquidity in the market completely dried up. We don't want to be in that position and we don't want to have to manage from that type of a position. So we will go slow, we'll be very disciplined in our investment and then we will work with the board on how we look at our dividends.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011

componenttext: The next question is from Chi Chow from Macquarie Capital.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, can you give us an update on the diesel export expansion timing? And what are the ultimate capacity you're looking for on exports?
componenttext: Gary, can you give us an update on the diesel export expansion timing? And what are the ultimate capacity you're looking for on exports?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, in fact, we've already started. Some of this is what we call debottleneck work, Chi, where you put in some additional lines to a dock or you put in -- you can tie in some additional tanks to a manifold in order to be able to get more product or to l
componenttext: Well, in fact, we've already started. Some of this is what we call debottleneck work, Chi, where you put in some additional lines to a dock or you put in -- you can tie in some additional tanks to a manifold in order to be able to get more product or to load faster at an export facility. So say we've already started some heavy engineering of complete on a couple of these projects. We do not have the detail yet on the amount of export, but I would say, Chi, it's kind of mid-2012 is when we would expect to have some additional capacity, and it's all at Garyville. It's what we're looking at right now, and it will come in stages. First, it will be some debottlenecking of some of the lines and some of our pumping capacity; and second, we'll look at maybe another tank in order to provide us somewhat additional optionality.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, the way we're kind of looking at things, Chi, and it's a very good question, but throughout the entire Q3, we've had the problems in Europe and it continues to grow. There've been some European refineries that had some upsets, but more so upsets in
componenttext: Well, the way we're kind of looking at things, Chi, and it's a very good question, but throughout the entire Q3, we've had the problems in Europe and it continues to grow. There've been some European refineries that had some upsets, but more so upsets in the Latin America-type refineries. So the global diesel demand continues to increase. But I think we're seeing is that maybe logistics are continuing to balance out different markets and move distillate that prior was either going into Europe or maybe Europe was moving a little bit more towards the med [ph] and some of their refining is that logistics is changing some of those patterns. And if anything, we're continuing to see it increase and continue to see more robust response to the export volumes that we have available each week.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's great. And then, finally, just a couple of housekeeping things. Looks like G&A expenses were up quarter-over-quarter in 3Q. Do you have any guidance on that and going forward? And then did you have any derivative gains in the refining results
componenttext: Okay. That's great. And then, finally, just a couple of housekeeping things. Looks like G&A expenses were up quarter-over-quarter in 3Q. Do you have any guidance on that and going forward? And then did you have any derivative gains in the refining results in the quarter?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chi, this is Don. Let me answer the second question. We did have -- consistent with prior quarters, we did have derivative activity and we had a $258 million gain in this quarter. And then with respect to your question on G&A, we're estimating as a standa
componenttext: Chi, this is Don. Let me answer the second question. We did have -- consistent with prior quarters, we did have derivative activity and we had a $258 million gain in this quarter. And then with respect to your question on G&A, we're estimating as a standalone company that we will have incremental costs of roughly $80 million on a normalized basis per year, yes, annually, per year. The SG&A item, one of the contributors to that, it was about $15 million of costs related to credit card fees in there. There's an offset in revenues, so some of that increase this quarter was just a function of our brand marketing, credit card fees and increase in the price of product.

componenttext: Doug, I unfortunately don't have anymore insights than what we're all reading in the paper. We've done a tremendous amount of work and continue to be leaders. I'll be in D.C. the next couple of days working on a number of issues, this being one of those issues. And it appears to us the majority of the work is complete within the environmental impact study. Now things tend to be tied up around the aquifer in Nebraska. And so I would say that, that seems to have slowed the process down. Still seem to get favorable comments out of the administration, but I don't know how long this issue in Nebraska may delay things.

componenttext: Right. And Doug, we plan on giving more details just in our November call, because we're in the midst right now of finalizing some agreements, but we certainly have an appetite to do that and we think we're going to do it with relatively low investment?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Garry Peiffer. No, I think you've hit the major points. I mean, as we showed on Page 8 of the slide deck that we just reviewed, and this is not much different than what we've talked about in the past. The biggest difference versus the past, obviou
componenttext: This is Garry Peiffer. No, I think you've hit the major points. I mean, as we showed on Page 8 of the slide deck that we just reviewed, and this is not much different than what we've talked about in the past. The biggest difference versus the past, obviously, is the WTI LLS is now a few dollars like we showed back in the last year. It's now obviously, in the third quarter of '11, almost $23. So when you add up about 50% of the sweet/sour differential, and I might note on that schedule or on that slide, we define it based upon what we would expect to run on an annualized basis of different types of crudes. That changes quarter-to-quarter and it changes by how individual companies tend to calculate that number. And then the other big thing for us, obviously, is the crack spread for the U.S. Gulf Coast and Chicago. So you've hit the major point but the big one now and we kind of laid out in that table to help a little bit is WTI were running, that also had a big impact versus LLS this quarter.

componenttext: And final question. Gary, can you give us some insight at how's the M&A market looking like? componenttext: Well, I wouldn't go so far as to say that our billing forward as your that we may be considering that. componenttext: I'd say we're pretty close to being there today. componenttext: You mentioned in your prepared remarks how you got to a 38% of your crude slate being benchmarked to WTI or Canadian heavy. headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Faisel, I can clarify that. As you know, the Keystone trunk line was completed mid-2010. And it takes time to kind of debottleneck both at the origin point, as well as destination when you get a new trunk line like that put into place. So we've been
componenttext: Yes, Faisel, I can clarify that. As you know, the Keystone trunk line was completed mid-2010. And it takes time to kind of debottleneck both at the origin point, as well as destination when you get a new trunk line like that put into place. So we've been continually doing that month-to-month. So our objective continues to be to bring in as much Canadian crude as economically makes sense for us. And there are various things that we're doing to enable that to happen, and that'll continue in the future.

So that's really the point we're trying to make to everyone.

componenttext: Gary just a follow-up on your thoughts on things like Brent TI and LLS TI. You all, obviously, are more of a PADD II Midwest refining company. And I guess I'm really thinking about the period before things like Keystone XL and some of the other pipelines come on. In the period before that, do you see any reason why being a Midwest refiner, the spreads could close on you faster than the folks in the Rockies?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q3 2011 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Arjun, the big new play, which is in the heart of our pipeline system, will be -- it's going to be more of a gathering system-type play than a trunk line. The majority of our pipeline systems today are trunk line. But obviously, the Utica, being rig
componenttext: Well, Arjun, the big new play, which is in the heart of our pipeline system, will be -- it's going to be more of a gathering system-type play than a trunk line. The majority of our pipeline systems today are trunk line. But obviously, the Utica, being right here in our backyard, could have some opportunity around a gathering and a kind of distributing or transporting from a lease custody transfer-type point. Back to your question on PADD IV versus PADD II, and you really think about how the pipelines move. Today, all of PADD IV is saturated with the amount of crude that goes directly to the refineries, and the majority of that is going to go either by either gathering system or truck. So I definitely agree with Mike that the systems as you export all those systems again will move west to east or a little bit south and then to the east, that I believe that they will go hand in hand because all of those refineries today will be completely full with those type of production is coming out of either Canada, the Bakken, the Niobrara, some of those areas.

componenttext: Lots of questions on WTI, so let's shift to another region. Cushing stocks are down, but most of the decline has happened on the Gulf Coast. And with the SPR release which you guys benefited from purchases there, it kind of depressed Gulf Coast crude pricing and enclosed the ARB for imports. During the month of August, imports remained pretty low, I guess, as people shift as best they can to Mid-Continent and cheaper feedstocks. How do you expect the Gulf Coast to play out as we move forward? And the imports stay low, inventory stay low, or do you see a change as we move through the end of the year and into 2012 there?

componenttext: Yes, I think -- this is Mike Palmer. With the ARB being closed, even though it's come in a bit in the last 10 days to 14 days, we still are not seeing very many opportunities on cargo crude that works for us. So I would not expect things to change much from where they've been in the last few months.
