componenttext: Yes, I think you'd be at -- from that number, annually, you'd be generating free cash flow just on your quarterly cash flow on this quarter. Just finally, on the level of debt, I guess, that you would consider you want to carry and above which -- any cash above which would be considered excess to requirement, and that will be it for me. If you could just indicate what that level is.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Don. We'll regularly evaluate sort of our debt level. Right now, we're at roughly $3.3 billion. We just went out with those senior notes, that are relatively new. I'm not anticipating in the short term that we're going to make a change eithe
componenttext: Paul, this is Don. We'll regularly evaluate sort of our debt level. Right now, we're at roughly $3.3 billion. We just went out with those senior notes, that are relatively new. I'm not anticipating in the short term that we're going to make a change either way.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arjun Murti of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arjun Murti of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, in your opening remarks, you noted, obviously, the very wide Brent TI spreads, LLS TI spreads and the challenges in the takeaway capacity out of the region for crude oil supply leading to these spreads. Can you talk about some of the solutions you s
componenttext: Gary, in your opening remarks, you noted, obviously, the very wide Brent TI spreads, LLS TI spreads and the challenges in the takeaway capacity out of the region for crude oil supply leading to these spreads. Can you talk about some of the solutions you see? I think everyone's familiar with  the longer-term pipeline options. But before those pipelines barge into something I think Marathon has some expertise in, what is the practical capacity that you can take barging volumes through? Can you give any economics of the kind of differential or costs associated with that? And maybe beyond barging, what are some of the other shorter-term options you see before the pipeline solutions come into play?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Arjun, that's a -- multipart question, and let me say there are many competing factors that really I think are causing these WTIs, the LLS-WTI spreads. We go back to the first part of the year and really review the sweet, light sweet crudes that are
componenttext: Well, Arjun, that's a -- multipart question, and let me say there are many competing factors that really I think are causing these WTIs, the LLS-WTI spreads. We go back to the first part of the year and really review the sweet, light sweet crudes that are required in the world, because of the ultralow sulfur fuels that need to be manufactured in Europe and some other refineries in Asia, that's number one, followed by the Libya problems. And so it really depends on when we see Libya crude coming on. That might affect the total global value of Brent and therefore, pulling LLS along with that. So then I bring you back domestically and what happens, and you kind of look out that corridor from Canada, all the way to the Gulf Coast. Absolutely, there's a talk of a big pipeline that's going to go from Cushing down to the Gulf Coast. But as I've said many times publicly, I don't believe that is the ultimate answer. It all is going to come back to how much Bakken is produced and what the rate of growth is in the Bakken. Then, you have a new competing factor as you go down to the southern part, down towards the Gulf in the Eagle Ford coming on and coming on very strong. At one time, it was determined that, oh, just the pipelines of the Gulf Coast would take the pressure off of Cushing and take the pressure of some of these WTI-type crudes in the North. But now, you have that new pressure point being the Eagle Ford. Yes, partially on the rivers is a very small solution, I would say. And it's not so much the barge traffic, Arjun, as it is who has the capacity and how can you load barges in different markets up and down the river, is really, I think, the solution to your question. So today, that number is quite small in context with the total amount of crude that's moving into that marketplace. So a long-winded answer to I think a very complex issue driven by market dynamics, and I didn't even get into the incremental Canadian production that's going to be produced and eventually land in the Patoka, Wood River market as well. So all those things I just mentioned are going to compete against each other, which I think lends us towards a wider differentials for a longer period of time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, it's very helpful. I think, clearly, one of the key assumptions is crude oil supply growth out of the shale plays in Canada continues. So if we take that as a given and in the absence of pipelines and if barging is ultimately limited, can rails solv
componenttext: Gary, it's very helpful. I think, clearly, one of the key assumptions is crude oil supply growth out of the shale plays in Canada continues. So if we take that as a given and in the absence of pipelines and if barging is ultimately limited, can rails solve this problem or we really are waiting for the big pipelines, whatever year or decade that turns out to be?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, you're absolutely right. And, Arjun, let me turn it over to Mike Palmer here. Mike is our Senior Vice President of all of our crude supply and knows the logistic systems very well. So let me ask Mike to make a few comments on this issue.
componenttext: Well, you're absolutely right. And, Arjun, let me turn it over to Mike Palmer here. Mike is our Senior Vice President of all of our crude supply and knows the logistic systems very well. So let me ask Mike to make a few comments on this issue.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arjun. We've looked at this pretty carefully, and I think Gary's pretty well hit it right on the nose. When you look at either barging or rail or trucking, which would be the other alternative to a pipe, the assets just don't exist. And what can be d
componenttext: Yes, Arjun. We've looked at this pretty carefully, and I think Gary's pretty well hit it right on the nose. When you look at either barging or rail or trucking, which would be the other alternative to a pipe, the assets just don't exist. And what can be done is in such small volumes that with the continued growth that we see in the shale plays as well as in Canada, we just don't think it makes a difference. So bottom line, until, we believe, until one of these pipeline projects actually comes to fruition, I mean it's very unlikely that we're going to see these spreads come together a lot.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Arjun, let me make one other point. When you look at the refineries across the Mid-Continent today and those refineries that kind of go from Oklahoma to Ohio, all of those refineries have their own pipeline systems servicing those refineries today. So
componenttext: And Arjun, let me make one other point. When you look at the refineries across the Mid-Continent today and those refineries that kind of go from Oklahoma to Ohio, all of those refineries have their own pipeline systems servicing those refineries today. So we don't require incremental pipeline space to be able to get the crude into those refineries. What is really required is some laterals, if you will, to be able to tie in to those systems that run to not just Marathon, but other refineries in the same region of the country today. And I think the competitive factors that I've mentioned earlier is what's going to still be the kind of the unknown dynamic of how fast this production comes on stream. Yes, eventually, there'll be some pipelines that can be put into service that may take some of this crude to the water, but I think that is a much longer time coming.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng out of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng out of Barclays Capital.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, along to Arjun's question, I just want to say more specifically for Marathon, your Midwest system represent 54% of your total capacity, your TI length is at 35%. So what step you could be taking to move that TI length much closer to 54% and how quic
componenttext: Gary, along to Arjun's question, I just want to say more specifically for Marathon, your Midwest system represent 54% of your total capacity, your TI length is at 35%. So what step you could be taking to move that TI length much closer to 54% and how quickly you could do it?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Arjun -- excuse me, Paul, you were talking about Arjun's question. Believe me, we are working on many ideas as well to kind of fit in with the explanation I just gave on how you can do some laterals or what you could do to increase your uptake. They
componenttext: Well, Arjun -- excuse me, Paul, you were talking about Arjun's question. Believe me, we are working on many ideas as well to kind of fit in with the explanation I just gave on how you can do some laterals or what you could do to increase your uptake. They are not ready for prime time yet, so I don't want to get into those in detail yet, but we are working on what some of those opportunities can be. And when you look at -- when we say we have 50%, 54% of our refining capacity in the Mid-Continent, that's true, but also, a number of those barrels are supplied into the Gulf. Some could be imported and we're looking at many different advantage crudes. So it's not always just a barrel that's coming in, a WTI-type barrel. And the other big thing is when we finish DHOUP, WCS so that the heavy Canadian will be a big part of our appetite, not only around Detroit, but we're running some derivatives, if you will, around -- of heavy crudes to some of our other plants in the Midwest also.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, is Detroit currently getting the crude supply from the in-land crude, including the onshore and Lower 48 and Canadian or are they just really getting more in the offshore crude?
componenttext: Gary, is Detroit currently getting the crude supply from the in-land crude, including the onshore and Lower 48 and Canadian or are they just really getting more in the offshore crude?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me ask Mike Palmer to discuss that.
componenttext: Let me ask Mike Palmer to discuss that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, at Detroit, the heavy supply that we bring in today is pretty much all Canadian. That's where the values really are. In the rest of the slate, it's a mix. It's both Canadian crude, as well as crude that we bring in from the Lower 48 and sometim
componenttext: Yes, Paul, at Detroit, the heavy supply that we bring in today is pretty much all Canadian. That's where the values really are. In the rest of the slate, it's a mix. It's both Canadian crude, as well as crude that we bring in from the Lower 48 and sometimes, its cargo crude. So it's a real mix. It depends upon the crude economics at that point in time, that we evaluate continuously.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could add 2 quick questions. One, Gary, in the process, you guys have said pipeline MLP is not really fit into what you guys want to do because then, the pipeline is really a a strategic asset. One thing, if that have any change since now t
componenttext: Okay. And if I could add 2 quick questions. One, Gary, in the process, you guys have said pipeline MLP is not really fit into what you guys want to do because then, the pipeline is really a a strategic asset. One thing, if that have any change since now that you're an independent company, do you wonder?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, Paul. And let me just -- back to your other question, I just want to add one more thing. We've always, probably said about 20,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadians, what we take in to Detroit today. So I want you to know that the incremental -- th
componenttext: Right, Paul. And let me just -- back to your other question, I just want to add one more thing. We've always, probably said about 20,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadians, what we take in to Detroit today. So I want you to know that the incremental -- the 80 was on top of that 20. So I just want to clear that up. Yes, Paul, a very good question on the MLP, and as always, we continue to do our homework. But as illustrated in the market today with the big WTI-LLS differentials, the flexibility that our system gives us today, has given us historically, and we believe will give us the flexibility to monetize into the future. We think it's just greater than the value of putting it off into an MLP. So as we said, 32 days old in our new company here, we still are going down the fairway that we think those assets live best within our corporate structure.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. A final one, really quick one, and this is for Garry Peiffer. Earlier, Garry, you were talking about the derivative gain is really matching the benchmark indicator. I presume you are referring to the cash earning, not the report earnings. Because in
componenttext: Okay. A final one, really quick one, and this is for Garry Peiffer. Earlier, Garry, you were talking about the derivative gain is really matching the benchmark indicator. I presume you are referring to the cash earning, not the report earnings. Because in LIFO, the report earnings that you saw already, I mean it doesn't matter which barrels that you reported. It's always based on the latest cost already. So am I interpret your comment correctly or that you're really talking about the report earnings did not -- will not have changed at all?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it wouldn't have changed at all. It's kind of a -- the absolute, we're seeing for the most part, the way the derivatives that we put in place -- maybe just to step back a minute. Paul, we've a got a lot of conversations about derivatives and many ye
componenttext: Well, it wouldn't have changed at all. It's kind of a -- the absolute, we're seeing for the most part, the way the derivatives that we put in place -- maybe just to step back a minute. Paul, we've a got a lot of conversations about derivatives and many years ago, we used to use the synthetic T-plus [ph] approach to price our domestic barrels, which we were buying. And as you recall, we changed that approach on our domestic purchases a few years ago, and now we do the calendar month average or we contract with our domestic suppliers to buy the crude on a basis that, basically, is at the same time that we refine the crude and refine products. So we are able to price those domestic barrels that we buy basically at the same time as we refine the barrels. The foreign crude, though we don't have that ability to use a contract arrangement to do it, so we use financial instruments, derivatives, to essentially allow us to price the crude into our refineries at approximately the same time as we refine them. So we're mimicking, to a pretty a great extent, what is going on with the crack spread indicators. Because, as you know, the crack spread is basically nothing more than comparing the current spot values of the refined products to the prompt month price of crude, which is next month's price. So in our case, what we're doing with those derivatives, and you're right, when you get into LIFO we are -- once we take those barrels into the -- take title to them, they come into our system. But basically, the answer is that all we're doing is mimicking the crack spreads that all of us follow every day in terms of what are, what we make on those barrels in that particular month.

componenttextpreview: Okay. One other one for me. Gary, I assume that you're a significant seller of RINs, gasoline RINs at this point. Can you give me an idea if that's true, what kind of contribution that makes? And in your mind, is that type of business vulnerable at all to
componenttext: Okay. One other one for me. Gary, I assume that you're a significant seller of RINs, gasoline RINs at this point. Can you give me an idea if that's true, what kind of contribution that makes? And in your mind, is that type of business vulnerable at all to the phaseout of the tax credit on ethanol?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Garry Peiffer. No, we're not a seller of RINs. A few years ago, I think you're right, when we were -- a few years ago, we were, but we generated more than we particularly needed and particularly able -- lately, this year, we're buying on the ne
componenttext: Mark, it's Garry Peiffer. No, we're not a seller of RINs. A few years ago, I think you're right, when we were -- a few years ago, we were, but we generated more than we particularly needed and particularly able -- lately, this year, we're buying on the neighborhood of maybe around $10 million worth of RINs a month or expensing about $10 million worth of RINs a month. And that's really being driven by the biodiesel RINs or the pricing RINs that we have to come up with in our system. So no, we're not a net seller, we're a net buyer to the tune of, like I said, about $10 million a month.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was going to go back to the WTI-LLS topic and ask about the current market. We see Cushing inventories declining, perhaps not as much as seasonal norms, but they're declining nonetheless. PADD II refining utilization is very high, mid-90s, so high deman
componenttext: I was going to go back to the WTI-LLS topic and ask about the current market. We see Cushing inventories declining, perhaps not as much as seasonal norms, but they're declining nonetheless. PADD II refining utilization is very high, mid-90s, so high demand for crude. Bakken growth has slowed because of weather and we've got the SPR putting 30 million barrels of LLS into the market. All of those factors would argue for a narrowing WTI-LLS, yet, we're at the widest point, about 25 barrels -- $25 a barrel today. Could you provide some insight as to why it's widening here in demand-strong peak season of the month -- of the year?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me ask Mike to cover this.
componenttext: Yes, let me ask Mike to cover this.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a very good question because it's just difficult to figure out. And I think what I would say is that probably, at this point, the things that you're talking about at Cushing are absolutely true. And, in fact, if you look at the inter-month spr
componenttext: Yes, that's a very good question because it's just difficult to figure out. And I think what I would say is that probably, at this point, the things that you're talking about at Cushing are absolutely true. And, in fact, if you look at the inter-month spreads that you see in the marketplace today, it reflects exactly what you're saying. People aren't too concerned about Cushing, there's plenty of storage, the refineries are processing a lot, so containment's not an issue. But I guess what I would say is that when you look at kind of the macro dynamics that are going on, there is just a lot of money flow that wants to go into Brent versus WTI. And I think that's the only way you can explain the very, very wide spreads that we see today, because there's certainly no formula that will give you the numbers that we're at, just slightly under $23.

componenttext: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. It's primarily driven -- that switch is primarily driven, when we sold our Minnesota refinery last year, St. Paul Park, we've kind of backed off. componenttext: Evan, I think it's a little too early to begin to that level of detail or really that level of competitive knowledge. componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of update on the same-store sales? I know in the quarter, you said you were down 5% year-over-year. I'm just trying to figure out where we're trending. Are we still down 5% into July or we did a little bit better or how are we
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of update on the same-store sales? I know in the quarter, you said you were down 5% year-over-year. I'm just trying to figure out where we're trending. Are we still down 5% into July or we did a little bit better or how are we looking here until August?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Faisel, I'm really pleased that you asked that question because at the first quarter earnings call, we spoke to our same-store sales and gasoline volume being down. And let me kind of step back and help everyone recall the second quarter of 2010 and how w
componenttext: Faisel, I'm really pleased that you asked that question because at the first quarter earnings call, we spoke to our same-store sales and gasoline volume being down. And let me kind of step back and help everyone recall the second quarter of 2010 and how we led through the balance of the year. And really, as I want everybody to recall, that there was some circumstances outside of our control or anybody else's control that I think really changed a lot of market dynamics of our customers for buying their transportation fuels in the second, third and partially, the fourth quarter of last year. But specifically, the second quarter of 2010, we were up 5% when the market was probably only up about 1% or so. So we picked up a lot of volume that I think was being switched from some other refiners during that period of time. Now this year, we're comparing ourselves on a same-store basis against the same period last year, and we're down, we said, 4%, 4.5% in the second quarter of 2011. So really, we're comparing against a very big increase in the same quarter last year, and now, we hear the market is down this year in the 2% range. So we've still been able to hang on to some of that market share we picked up last year, but clearly, we didn't hang on to all of that. Then in July, we're comparing against last year, we were up about 10% in the month of July on a same-store basis. So we certainly wouldn't expect to hang on to that same amount this year, and we're down this year of almost 4% versus being up 10% last year. So you can see in July, we're still hanging on to a lot of the market share we picked up, but those -- that big circumstance really was outside of our control last year.

componenttext: There isn't -- and one other key thing that -- I spoke about this a little bit on the first quarter call, was we calculate approximately 1% drop just in demand because of weather that was across the entire Mid-Continent here in the second quarter. Now we had very, very heavy rains in May and then again in different parts of June. So -- and that just doesn't come back. That's probably just a 1% decline in this overall demand.

componenttext: Okay. So I guess excluding all these sort of comparison issues, where would you say we were for July in terms of real demand growth across your system? componenttext: I would say gasoline demand, what has happened is if we compare same period this year versus same period last year, we're up about $0.85 a gallon in retail price, about $2.69 last year in the second quarter, $3.74 this year. Month-to-date, we're about $3.72. So I'd say gasoline price has, would have a bigger effect on the overall demand, but the kind of -- put a barometer on it, I would say, Faisel, we're probably down in the 2% to 3% range in overall gasoline demand.

componenttext: Okay, understood. And then one question. On the -- I heard you guys, your earlier comments on the derivatives, on the derivative gain, is that a cash gain or is there any mark-to-market impact in those numbers?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. We mark to market everything. Every month, every quarter, we mark to market all of our derivative activity, but most of our derivative activity is only a month or 2 out. So for the most part, it is cash. Very little of that $23
componenttext: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. We mark to market everything. Every month, every quarter, we mark to market all of our derivative activity, but most of our derivative activity is only a month or 2 out. So for the most part, it is cash. Very little of that $234 million gain relates to activities that'll come through in the next month or so, so the majority -- almost all of that $234 million was cash that, from a derivative standpoint, we benefited from in the second quarter or that was offsetting negative effects from the commodity side as well. So it was basically cash for cash in the second quarter with very little carryover effect beyond the second quarter.

componenttext: And I think as you might've heard from Don, Don's discussion when we looked at cash, we have pretty substantial increases in inventories in the second quarter. headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I probably would be remiss, Blake, if I didn't really say thank you to Clarence Cazalot for all the tremendous capital that he allowed us to invest in the downstream. We were a contrary. We've got the most companies the investor liked more in our
componenttext: Yes, and I probably would be remiss, Blake, if I didn't really say thank you to Clarence Cazalot for all the tremendous capital that he allowed us to invest in the downstream. We were a contrary. We've got the most companies the investor liked more in our downstream versus others. But I wouldn't say that -- I'd never go on and say that we're starved for capital. I thought we had plenty of capital to say grace over. But with some things that we have found, it's been very clear that Garyville is operating significantly above its design capacity, when that happens, then you're producing a lot more product in certain steps of the process units. Therefore, that you might need some room for in -- as you run those process units, which draws me back to the de-bottlenecking. So not big projects, but we think some very significant rates of return-type projects that we will see down the road. But again, I don't believe that we were ever starved for capital.

componenttext: A couple of questions. First, going back to growth of the Speedway market, can you just provide a little bit more color in terms of what the criteria that you look for when you look for retail sites? And also, sort of kind of what level you're looking to get to in terms of the amount of throughput that you have that goes through those sites, where you are currently and where you would like to get to in any timeframe in terms of which you would like to achieve that objective?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, Ann. Here in the Midwest, 8 or 9 states that Speedway operates, we're very pleased with the tremendous integration we have between the gasoline volume and the merchandise sales. But what we're talking about is wanting thing to branch out and be abl
componenttext: Right, Ann. Here in the Midwest, 8 or 9 states that Speedway operates, we're very pleased with the tremendous integration we have between the gasoline volume and the merchandise sales. But what we're talking about is wanting thing to branch out and be able to move closer to either the colonial or plantation system, where we can deliver Garyville barrels through our proprietary terminal system that we already have. We think that gives us a very good fit and now we can capture the entire supply chain. So in and around the Midwest where we already operate, we will continue to want to fill out some of our markets where there are new interstate locations or new subdivisions being built, so on and so forth. But as we go, as we move into the Southeast -- and you'll recall, we used to be in a number of states in the Southeast, but we didn't have very strong market share that, nor did we have the density to be able to really justify any big marketing campaigns. So as we look going into the Southeast, we will want to be closer to our marketing and terminal systems.

componenttext: This is Garry Peiffer again, Paul. No, not at this point. As I think we've said, I think that permit is good for 2 years. componenttext: Marathon Petroleum Corporation Second Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. My name is Monica, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Pam Beall. Pam Beall, you may begin.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Monica, and welcome everybody to Marathon's second quarter 2011 earnings call. Synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com. On the call today are Gary Heminger, our President and Chief Execu
componenttext:
Thank you, Monica, and welcome everybody to Marathon's second quarter 2011 earnings call. Synchronized slides that accompany this call can be found on our website at marathonpetroleum.com. On the call today are Gary Heminger, our President and Chief Executive Officer; Garry Peiffer, Executive Vice President of Corporate Planning and Investor and Government Relations; and Don Templin, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
If you turn to Slide 2, you'll see it contains a discussion of forward-looking statements and other information included in this presentation. Our remarks and answers to questions today will contain forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by such statements. In accordance with safe harbor provision of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, Marathon Petroleum Corporation has included in its Form 10, filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and earnings release issued earlier today, cautionary language identifying important factors but not necessarily all factors that could cause future outcomes to differ materially from those set forth in the forward-looking statements.
Please note that in the appendix to this presentation is a reconciliation of quarterly net income to adjusted net income and other data that you may find useful.
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Gary Heminger for some opening remarks.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Pam. If you go to Slide 3, as you know, Marathon Petroleum Company Corporation was filed from Marathon Oil Corporation effective June 30, 2011. This transaction was executed as planned and we now have all of our people, processes and financing
componenttext:
Thank you, Pam. If you go to Slide 3, as you know, Marathon Petroleum Company Corporation was filed from Marathon Oil Corporation effective June 30, 2011. This transaction was executed as planned and we now have all of our people, processes and financing in place to operate as a best-in-class independent downstream company. We have a strong balance sheet, an investment grade credit rating and a number of projects under way that we believe position us well for earnings and cash flow growth. On July 27 of 2011, we declared our first quarterly dividend of $0.20 per share payable on September 12 of 2011, to the shareholders of record on August 17 of 2011.
During the second quarter, we continued the optimization of our expanded Garyville refinery and increased our distillate exports from Garyville to approximately 70,000 barrels per day. With modest additional investments, we believe we can increase our distillate exports, providing us with additional options to place production in higher-value markets. Upgrades to our Detroit refinery are approximately 63% complete. This project remains on budget and on schedule for completion in the second half of 2012. This project will allow us -- I should say, should allow us to process an incremental 80,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadian crude, lower our feedstock cost and increase Detroit's crude oil refining capacity about 15% to 120,000 barrels per day.
During the second quarter, we continued to benefit from wider differentials between West Texas Intermediate and other light sweet crudes, as well as the differential between LLS and our normal slate of sour crudes. This increased our income from operations despite further signs of a weak economy. During the second quarter, 50% of the crude we processed was sour. Leveraging our logistics systems, we were able to increase the amount of the crude we processed that was linked to WTI pricing and Canadian heavy to about 35%, up from approximately 33% in the first quarter and about 25% in the fourth quarter of 2010. If oil production in North America continues to grow faster than the logistics to deliver this production to consuming markets, we expect wider differentials to continue. 
During the second quarter of 2011, Speedway completed the purchase of 23 convenience stores in Chicago, Illinois and Northwest Indiana, which strengthens its presence in this important geographic area. All of the locations have been rebranded under the Speedway flag, and we are very pleased with the initial results of these operations. This is a segment of the business we intend to grow in contiguous areas through a combination of greenfield sites and selective acquisitions.
At our Speedway retail business, we realized strong gasoline and distillate gross margins during the quarter. This partially offset the impact of lower gasoline and distillate sales volumes, primarily associated with our 166 convenience stores sold as part of the December 2010 sale of our Minnesota refinery and related assets. The spinoff of Marathon Petroleum from Marathon Oil Corporation effective June 30, 2011, was the right transaction at the right time. Our fully integrated approach and sharp business focus provide operational flexibility and the ability to efficiently move petroleum-related products through our system.
Looking ahead, not only do we expect to continue to benefit from the Garyville expansion, which is in full production and is operating above its nameplate crude oil refining capacity, but also our Detroit Heavy Oil Upgrading Project should come online during the second half of next year. We are also optimistic about the growth prospects for our Speedway retail operations. We expect these investments to enhance our earnings and our cash flow for many years to come. 
And now, I'll turn it over to Don Templin, who will review the financial results for the quarter. Don?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Gary. Slide 4 provides net income and adjusted net income data both on an absolute and per share basis. Our second quarter 2011 adjusted net income of $819 million reflects a 94% increase from the $422 million earned in the second quarter of 20
componenttext:
Thank you, Gary. Slide 4 provides net income and adjusted net income data both on an absolute and per share basis. Our second quarter 2011 adjusted net income of $819 million reflects a 94% increase from the $422 million earned in the second quarter of 2010. 
The waterfall chart on Slide 5 shows by segment the change in adjusted net income from the second quarter of 2010 to the second quarter of 2011. The primary reason for the increase in our adjusted net income was the increase in Refining and Marketing income, partially offset by higher income taxes. For the 2011 second quarter, the effective income tax rate was 40% compared with 37% in the second quarter of 2010.
Our 2011 tax rate was impacted by changes in state income tax legislation, primarily in Michigan. This resulted in a $17 million tax charge during the 2011 second quarter that has been treated as a special item. 
The Refining and Marketing variance analysis is shown on Slide 6. Refining and Marketing segment income from operations was $1.26 billion in the second quarter of 2011 compared with $590 million in the second quarter of 2010. This increase was primarily the result of higher Refining and Marketing gross margin, which I will discuss on the next slide. Before I do that, I wanted to explain the $63 million in other items. This change is primarily due to higher refined product transportation costs and incremental incentive compensation accrual due to our strong results during the first half of 2011. 
Slide 7 shows a few of the economic drivers contributing to the improved Refining and Marketing gross margin for the second quarter. Our gross margin in the second quarter of 2011 benefited from a wider WTI-LLS differential, a wider sweet-sour differential and higher Chicago and U.S. Gulf Coast crack spreads.
The WTI-LLS differential has clearly increased nearly $12 per barrel from an average of $4.11 per barrel in the second quarter of 2010 to $16.09 per barrel in the second quarter of 2011. The sweet-sour differential increased approximately 25% from an average of $8.78 per barrel in the second quarter of 2010 to $11.08 per barrel in the second quarter of 2011. 
In addition, our blended Chicago and U.S. Gulf Coast LLS crack spread increased from $3.20 per barrel in the second quarter of 2010 to $5.53 per barrel in the second quarter of 2011.
Our average refinery inputs were 1,372,000 barrels per day or 21,000 barrels per day lower than the second quarter of last year. This primarily reflects the impact of the December 2010 sale of the Minnesota refinery, partially offset by the Garyville major expansion, which is operating at higher rates than the comparable quarter last year. I should also mention that our Refining and Marketing results included higher derivative gains in the 2011 second quarter compared with the same period last year. While the pricing mechanism we have in place for domestic crudes allows us to price them close to the time they're refined without the use of derivatives, our foreign crude purchases start pricing as much as 2 months before we process them. As a result, we use derivatives to float the price of our foreign crude purchases until closer to the time we begin processing them. As a result, during the 2011 second quarter, derivative gains totaled $234 million compared with $73 million in the 2010 second quarter.
Turning to Slide 8. Speedway's income from operations was $80 million in the second quarter of 2011 compared with $83 million in the second quarter of 2010. Speedway's gasoline and distillate gross margin was about $10 million higher in the second quarter of 2011 compared with the second quarter of 2010. The higher gasoline and distillate gross margin, which increased from $0.117 per gallon in the second quarter of 2010 to $0.15 per gallon in the second quarter of 2011, was partially offset by lower refined product sales volumes. These reduced volumes were primarily associated with the 166 convenience stores that were part of the December 2010 sale of our Minnesota refinery and related assets. The lower merchandise gross margin dollars and lower expenses in the second quarter of 2011 also primarily reflects the effects of the Minnesota asset disposition.
Same-store gasoline sales decreased 5% and same-store merchandise sales were flat in the second quarter of 2011 compared with the 2010 second quarter. The lower same-store sales reflect weaker demand and the impact of the higher price level of gasoline. The average retail gasoline price was $3.74 per gallon during the second quarter of 2011 compared with $2.69 per gallon for the comparable quarter last year. In July 2011, we continued to see lower demand with an approximately 4% decrease in same-store gasoline sales, which we believe is a result of the weak economic recovery in the United States. 
Slide 9 shows the Pipeline Transportation segment income. Income from operations was $54 million in the second quarter of 2011 compared with $48 million in the second quarter of 2010, primarily associated with increased volumes that were transported.
The table on Slide 10 provides an analysis of cash flows for the second quarter of 2011. At June 30, 2011, our cash balance was $1,622,000,000. Operating cash flow before changes in working capital was $1,068,000,000. The working capital changes of $1,031,000,000 noted on the slide primarily relate to a seasonal increase in inventory volumes. Capital expenditures and investments during the quarter were $345 million, primarily related to our Detroit Heavy Oil refinery project and the acquisition of 23 convenience stores. This slide also reflects the various cash movements required to implement this end transaction. We expect capital spending for the full year 2011 will be approximately $1.3 billion, including approximately $158 million of capitalized interest and corporate items. 
Slide 11 shows that at the end of the second quarter, we had $1.6 billion of cash and approximately $3.3 billion of debt. Our cash adjusted debt-to-capital ratio was 16%. On July 1, 2011, we completed a new trade receivable securitization facility in an aggregate principal amount not to exceed $1 billion. Along with our $1.6 billion in cash and our $2 billion revolving credit facility, this should provide us with significant flexibility to manage our operations and to pursue value-enhancing organic growth opportunities and selective acquisitions.
As we look forward, we expect our refining crude oil inputs to be approximately 1.2 million barrels per day for 2011 versus 1.1 million barrels per day for 2010 in spite of the fact that we sold the Minnesota refinery effective December 1, 2010. As you know, our historical corporate costs do not reflect all of the costs of operating as a standalone company. We estimate these costs will total an incremental $50 million pretax on a normalized annual basis.
Finally, assuming no other special items during the remainder of 2011, we expect the overall income tax rate to be approximately 38% for the full year. 
Now I will turn the call back to Pam Beall.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: My question's on Garyville's performance in relation to the expectation when the plant was streamed last spring, meaning you guys have always seemed pretty confident that you'd be able to perform well at that plant, but it seems that production and yield
componenttext: My question's on Garyville's performance in relation to the expectation when the plant was streamed last spring, meaning you guys have always seemed pretty confident that you'd be able to perform well at that plant, but it seems that production and yield are exceeding expectations. And so, I just wondered if you can provide some insight on this item and really any expectation that you may have for future progress at that facility.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Doug, this is Gary, and thank you for your comment. Yes, we are performing very well. We're very pleased with the design engineering and the operation there at Garyville. You'll recall last fall, we did request an increase in the permit, then it was
componenttext: Well, Doug, this is Gary, and thank you for your comment. Yes, we are performing very well. We're very pleased with the design engineering and the operation there at Garyville. You'll recall last fall, we did request an increase in the permit, then it was approved, and we've been operating well above its nameplate capacity, have now increased the total capacity, nameplate capacity to 464,000 barrels per day. Both on the crude side and on some of the other process units we've been outpacing, we believe we have some additional work that we could do to even de-bottleneck further as we go into 2012. I don't have the details yet, Doug, nor the engineering complete on what that will be, but we certainly see upside in the plant even for what its operating today, which I said earlier, is significantly above its nameplate capacity.

componenttext: Good, I'm glad that's cleared up. Just on the operational cash flow, a very strong number, $1.07 billion CapEx in the quarter of, as you said, about the free cash flow, about $700 million. Can we talk a little bit about after DHOUP or even before, what are you planning to do with this excess free cash flow, I'm thinking particularly in terms of returns of cash to shareholders?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Ed, this is Don Templin. I guess first and foremost, we want to make sure that we maintain our investment credit profile, so that's what the underlying objective of many of the things that we will be doing. And then I think secondly, we're going to look f
componenttext: Ed, this is Don Templin. I guess first and foremost, we want to make sure that we maintain our investment credit profile, so that's what the underlying objective of many of the things that we will be doing. And then I think secondly, we're going to look for opportunities, growth and value-enhancement opportunities that are both organic and inorganic. And I think then after that, we're going to make sure we're analyzing our sort of dividend policy and, as you know, our board of directors regularly reviews this on a quarterly basis. So in terms of order of priority, I would say investing in the business and making sure we're taking advantage of both organic and inorganic opportunities will be our focus.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And given the cash flow generation, I presume this will be up for review at the next board meeting. When is that?
componenttext: And given the cash flow generation, I presume this will be up for review at the next board meeting. When is that?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: I'll ask a follow-up to that one, if I could. On cash uses, acquisitions, I think you've been fairly clear that a major refinery acquisition would be very unlikely, particularly something outside of your fairway, I guess I'll call it. And that, really, the kind of acquisitions you're talking about are more on the retail and much smaller area?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Paul, I think I've been very clear that we don't have any appetite to go across the Atlantic today nor go to the West Coast and just do a merchant type of an acquisition. But please understand, we do our homework and all of our analysis on anything
componenttext: Well, Paul, I think I've been very clear that we don't have any appetite to go across the Atlantic today nor go to the West Coast and just do a merchant type of an acquisition. But please understand, we do our homework and all of our analysis on anything that might be available and some that aren't always public that are available. So we do our analysis on all of those. But you are correct. Our plans right away are to continue to do, as Don just said, from the inorganic de-bottlenecking at Garyville, and I'm sure we will have some at Detroit once we finish the Heavy Oil Upgrading Project, which will give us some very good returns. I've stated that we want to continue to invest in our retail operation, both the Speedway and the Marathon brand, to continue our strong presence in the markets of which we serve, and then we will go from there.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: About $1 billion, okay, I'm sorry. About $1 billion left in total next year, Paul, which would include Detroit. Now that does not include some of these organic projects that Don spoke to, nor does it include -- we do have a fair amount of money in that number to be able to continue to invest in Speedway, but we don't have any major acquisitions in there. So as you can tell, though, $700 million to $800 million is still a very small number, I should say, based on what we have invested over the last 5 to 8 years.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Paul, this is Don. We'll regularly evaluate sort of our debt level. Right now, we're at roughly $3.3 billion. We just went out with those senior notes that are relatively new. I'm not anticipating in the short term that we're going to make a change either way.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Arjun Murti of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question comes from Arjun Murti of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, in your opening remarks, you noted, obviously, the very wide Brent TI spreads, LLS TI spreads and the challenges in the takeaway capacity out of the region for crude oil supply leading to these spreads. Can you talk about some of the solutions you s
componenttext: Gary, in your opening remarks, you noted, obviously, the very wide Brent TI spreads, LLS TI spreads and the challenges in the takeaway capacity out of the region for crude oil supply leading to these spreads. Can you talk about some of the solutions you see? I think everyone's familiar with  the longer-term pipeline options. But before those pipelines barge into something I think Marathon has some expertise in, what is the practical capacity that you can take barging volumes through? Can you give any economics of the kind of differential or costs associated with that? And maybe beyond barging, what are some of the other shorter-term options you see before the pipeline solutions come into play?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Arjun, that's a -- multipart question, and let me say there are many competing factors that really I think are causing these WTIs, the LLS-WTI spreads. We go back to the first part of the year and really review the sweet, light sweet crudes that are
componenttext: Well, Arjun, that's a -- multipart question, and let me say there are many competing factors that really I think are causing these WTIs, the LLS-WTI spreads. We go back to the first part of the year and really review the sweet, light sweet crudes that are required in the world, because of the ultralow sulfur fuels that need to be manufactured in Europe and some other refineries in Asia, that's number one, followed by the Libya problems. And so it really depends on when we see Libya crude coming on. That might affect the total global value of Brent and therefore, pulling LLS along with that. So then I bring you back domestically and what happens, and you kind of look out that corridor from Canada, all the way to the Gulf Coast. Absolutely, there's a talk of a big pipeline that's going to go from Cushing down to the Gulf Coast. But as I've said many times publicly, I don't believe that is the ultimate answer. It all is going to come back to how much Bakken is produced and what the rate of growth is in the Bakken. Then, you have a new competing factor as you go down to the southern part, down towards the Gulf in the Eagle Ford coming on and coming on very strong. At one time, it was determined that, oh, just the pipelines of the Gulf Coast would take the pressure off of Cushing and take the pressure of some of these WTI-type crudes in the North. But now, you have that new pressure point being the Eagle Ford. Yes, partially on the rivers is a very small solution, I would say. And it's not so much the barge traffic, Arjun, as it is who has the capacity and how can you load barges in different markets up and down the river, is really, I think, the solution to your question. So today, that number is quite small in context with the total amount of crude that's moving into that marketplace. So a long-winded answer to I think a very complex issue driven by market dynamics, and I didn't even get into the incremental Canadian production that's going to be produced and eventually land in the Patoka, Wood River market as well. So all those things I just mentioned are going to compete against each other, which I think lends us towards a wider differentials for a longer period of time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, it's very helpful. I think, clearly, one of the key assumptions is crude oil supply growth out of the shale plays in Canada continues. So if we take that as a given and in the absence of pipelines and if barging is ultimately limited, can rails solv
componenttext: Gary, it's very helpful. I think, clearly, one of the key assumptions is crude oil supply growth out of the shale plays in Canada continues. So if we take that as a given and in the absence of pipelines and if barging is ultimately limited, can rails solve this problem or we really are waiting for the big pipelines, whatever year or decade that turns out to be?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, you're absolutely right. And, Arjun, let me turn it over to Mike Palmer here. Mike is our Senior Vice President of all of our crude supply and knows the logistic systems very well. So let me ask Mike to make a few comments on this issue.
componenttext: Well, you're absolutely right. And, Arjun, let me turn it over to Mike Palmer here. Mike is our Senior Vice President of all of our crude supply and knows the logistic systems very well. So let me ask Mike to make a few comments on this issue.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Arjun. We've looked at this pretty carefully, and I think Gary's pretty well hit it right on the nose. When you look at either barging or rail or trucking, which would be the other alternative to a pipe, the assets just don't exist. And what can be d
componenttext: Yes, Arjun. We've looked at this pretty carefully, and I think Gary's pretty well hit it right on the nose. When you look at either barging or rail or trucking, which would be the other alternative to a pipe, the assets just don't exist. And what can be done is in such small volumes that with the continued growth that we see in the shale plays as well as in Canada, we just don't think it makes a difference. So bottom line, until, we believe, until one of these pipeline projects actually comes to fruition, I mean it's very unlikely that we're going to see these spreads come together a lot.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And Arjun, let me make one other point. When you look at the refineries across the Mid-Continent today and those refineries that kind of go from Oklahoma to Ohio, all of those refineries have their own pipeline systems servicing those refineries today. So
componenttext: And Arjun, let me make one other point. When you look at the refineries across the Mid-Continent today and those refineries that kind of go from Oklahoma to Ohio, all of those refineries have their own pipeline systems servicing those refineries today. So we don't require incremental pipeline space to be able to get the crude into those refineries. What is really required is some laterals, if you will, to be able to tie in to those systems that run to not just Marathon, but other refineries in the same region of the country today. And I think the competitive factors that I've mentioned earlier is what's going to still be the kind of the unknown dynamic of how fast this production comes on stream. Yes, eventually, there'll be some pipelines that can be put into service that may take some of this crude to the water, but I think that is a much longer time coming.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng out of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Paul Cheng out of Barclays Capital.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, along to Arjun's question, I just want to say more specifically for Marathon, your Midwest system represent 54% of your total capacity, your TI length is at 35%. So what step you could be taking to move that TI length much closer to 54% and how quic
componenttext: Gary, along to Arjun's question, I just want to say more specifically for Marathon, your Midwest system represent 54% of your total capacity, your TI length is at 35%. So what step you could be taking to move that TI length much closer to 54% and how quickly you could do it?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Arjun -- excuse me, Paul, you were talking about Arjun's question. Believe me, we are working on many ideas as well to kind of fit in with the explanation I just gave on how you can do some laterals or what you could do to increase your uptake. They
componenttext: Well, Arjun -- excuse me, Paul, you were talking about Arjun's question. Believe me, we are working on many ideas as well to kind of fit in with the explanation I just gave on how you can do some laterals or what you could do to increase your uptake. They are not ready for prime time yet, so I don't want to get into those in detail yet, but we are working on what some of those opportunities can be. And when you look at -- when we say we have 50%, 54% of our refining capacity in the Mid-Continent, that's true, but also, a number of those barrels are supplied into the Gulf. Some could be imported and we're looking at many different advantage crudes. So it's not always just a barrel that's coming in, a WTI-type barrel. And the other big thing is when we finish DHOUP, WCS so that the heavy Canadian will be a big part of our appetite, not only around Detroit, but we're running some derivatives, if you will, around -- of heavy crudes to some of our other plants in the Midwest also.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, is Detroit currently getting the crude supply from the in-land crude, including the onshore and Lower 48 and Canadian or are they just really getting more in the offshore crude?
componenttext: Gary, is Detroit currently getting the crude supply from the in-land crude, including the onshore and Lower 48 and Canadian or are they just really getting more in the offshore crude?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Let me ask Mike Palmer to discuss that.
componenttext: Let me ask Mike Palmer to discuss that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, Paul, at Detroit, the heavy supply that we bring in today is pretty much all Canadian. That's where the values really are. In the rest of the slate, it's a mix. It's both Canadian crude, as well as crude that we bring in from the Lower 48 and sometim
componenttext: Yes, Paul, at Detroit, the heavy supply that we bring in today is pretty much all Canadian. That's where the values really are. In the rest of the slate, it's a mix. It's both Canadian crude, as well as crude that we bring in from the Lower 48 and sometimes, its cargo crude. So it's a real mix. It depends upon the crude economics at that point in time that we evaluate continuously.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could add 2 quick questions. One, Gary, in the process, you guys have said pipeline MLP is not really fit into what you guys want to do because then, the pipeline is really a strategic asset. One thing, if that have any change since now tha
componenttext: Okay. And if I could add 2 quick questions. One, Gary, in the process, you guys have said pipeline MLP is not really fit into what you guys want to do because then, the pipeline is really a strategic asset. One thing, if that have any change since now that you're an independent company, do you wonder?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, Paul. And let me just -- back to your other question, I just want to add one more thing. We've always, probably said about 20,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadians, what we take in to Detroit today. So I want you to know that the incremental -- th
componenttext: Right, Paul. And let me just -- back to your other question, I just want to add one more thing. We've always, probably said about 20,000 barrels per day of heavy Canadians, what we take in to Detroit today. So I want you to know that the incremental -- the 80 was on top of that 20. So I just want to clear that up. Yes, Paul, a very good question on the MLP, and as always, we continue to do our homework. But as illustrated in the market today with the big WTI-LLS differentials, the flexibility that our system gives us today, has given us historically, and we believe will give us the flexibility to monetize into the future. We think it's just greater than the value of putting it off into an MLP. So as we said, 32 days old in our new company here, we still are going down the fairway that we think those assets live best within our corporate structure.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. A final one, really quick one, and this is for Garry Peiffer. Earlier, Garry, you were talking about the derivative gain is really matching the benchmark indicator. I presume you are referring to the cash earning, not the report earnings. Because in
componenttext: Okay. A final one, really quick one, and this is for Garry Peiffer. Earlier, Garry, you were talking about the derivative gain is really matching the benchmark indicator. I presume you are referring to the cash earning, not the report earnings. Because in LIFO, the report earnings that you saw already, I mean it doesn't matter which barrels that you reported. It's always based on the latest cost already. So am I interpreting your comment correctly or that you're really talking about the report earnings did not -- will not have changed at all?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, it wouldn't have changed at all. It's kind of a -- the absolute, we're seeing for the most part, the way the derivatives that we put in place -- maybe just to step back a minute. Paul, we've a got a lot of conversations about derivatives and many ye
componenttext: Well, it wouldn't have changed at all. It's kind of a -- the absolute, we're seeing for the most part, the way the derivatives that we put in place -- maybe just to step back a minute. Paul, we've a got a lot of conversations about derivatives and many years ago, we used to use the synthetic T-plus [ph] approach to price our domestic barrels, which we were buying. And as you recall, we changed that approach on our domestic purchases a few years ago, and now we do the calendar month average or we contract with our domestic suppliers to buy the crude on a basis that, basically, is at the same time that we refine the crude and refine products. So we are able to price those domestic barrels that we buy basically at the same time as we refine the barrels. The foreign crude, though we don't have that ability to use a contract arrangement to do it, so we use financial instruments, derivatives, to essentially allow us to price the crude into our refineries at approximately the same time as we refine them. So we're mimicking, to a pretty a great extent, what is going on with the crack spread indicators. Because, as you know, the crack spread is basically nothing more than comparing the current spot values of the refined products to the prompt month price of crude, which is next month's price. So in our case, what we're doing with those derivatives, and you're right, when you get into LIFO we are -- once we take those barrels into the -- take title to them, they come into our system. But basically, the answer is that all we're doing is mimicking the crack spreads that all of us follow every day in terms of what are, what we make on those barrels in that particular month.

componenttext: Well, we are in the process -- and let me, first of all, back up, Mark. Today, we move a lot of crude, about 100, maybe around just a little over 100,000 barrels per day. So obviously, we have the pipeline capacity to move those barrels into Detroit today, granted we're changing a slate and be a heavier slate. So we have many different avenues that we're working on to lock that in, but we feel very confident and we're in good shape on how we're going to be delivering that crude into Detroit going forward.

componenttext: That's not what I said. I said that we have many avenues, but I'm not going to get in publicly into what the firm transportation agreements we have are yet.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Nor is there necessarily a dedicated supply source at this point?
componenttext: Nor is there necessarily a dedicated supply source at this point?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: We do not have a dedicated supply source if that's what you're driving towards. It's always been our plan that we want to be a net buyer, if you will. And whatever the market value is and as we see the production continuing to increase in Canada and some
componenttext: We do not have a dedicated supply source if that's what you're driving towards. It's always been our plan that we want to be a net buyer, if you will. And whatever the market value is and as we see the production continuing to increase in Canada and some other opportunities in different fields coming out of Canada, we want to be, as I say, a market buyer.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Spot buyer.
componenttext: Spot buyer.

componenttextpreview: Spot buyer Is what I mean.
componenttext: Spot buyer Is what I mean.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. One other one for me. Gary, I assume that you're a significant seller of RINs, gasoline RINs at this point. Can you give me an idea if that's true, what kind of contribution that makes? And in your mind, is that type of business vulnerable at all to
componenttext: Okay. One other one for me. Gary, I assume that you're a significant seller of RINs, gasoline RINs at this point. Can you give me an idea if that's true, what kind of contribution that makes? And in your mind, is that type of business vulnerable at all to the phaseout of the tax credit on ethanol?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Mark, it's Garry Peiffer. No, we're not a seller of RINs. A few years ago, I think you're right, when we were -- a few years ago, we were, but we generated more than we particularly needed and particularly able -- lately, this year, we're buying on the ne
componenttext: Mark, it's Garry Peiffer. No, we're not a seller of RINs. A few years ago, I think you're right, when we were -- a few years ago, we were, but we generated more than we particularly needed and particularly able -- lately, this year, we're buying on the neighborhood of maybe around $10 million worth of RINs a month or expensing about $10 million worth of RINs a month. And that's really being driven by the biodiesel RINs or the pricing RINs that we have to come up with in our system. So no, we're not a net seller, we're a net buyer to the tune of, like I said, about $10 million a month.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Jeff Dietert of Simmons & Company.
componenttext: The next question comes from Jeff Dietert of Simmons & Company.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was going to go back to the WTI-LLS topic and ask about the current market. We see Cushing inventories declining, perhaps not as much as seasonal norms, but they're declining nonetheless. PADD II refining utilization is very high, mid-90s, so high deman
componenttext: I was going to go back to the WTI-LLS topic and ask about the current market. We see Cushing inventories declining, perhaps not as much as seasonal norms, but they're declining nonetheless. PADD II refining utilization is very high, mid-90s, so high demand for crude. Bakken growth has slowed because of weather and we've got the SPR putting 30 million barrels of LLS into the market. All of those factors would argue for a narrowing WTI-LLS, yet, we're at the widest point, about 25 barrels -- $25 a barrel today. Could you provide some insight as to why it's widening here in demand-strong peak season of the month -- of the year?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me ask Mike to cover this.
componenttext: Yes, let me ask Mike to cover this.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a very good question because it's just difficult to figure out. And I think what I would say is that probably, at this point, the things that you're talking about at Cushing are absolutely true. And, in fact, if you look at the inter-month spr
componenttext: Yes, that's a very good question because it's just difficult to figure out. And I think what I would say is that probably, at this point, the things that you're talking about at Cushing are absolutely true. And, in fact, if you look at the inter-month spreads that you see in the marketplace today, it reflects exactly what you're saying. People aren't too concerned about Cushing, there's plenty of storage, the refineries are processing a lot, so containment's not an issue. But I guess what I would say is that when you look at kind of the macro dynamics that are going on, there is just a lot of money flow that wants to go into Brent versus WTI. And I think that's the only way you can explain the very, very wide spreads that we see today, because there's certainly no formula that will give you the numbers that we're at, just slightly under $23.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. And secondly, on another topic, you provided information on this crudes in your sweet/sour differential. As I compare the '07 to 2010 period to the 2011 period, Western Canadian Select is down 5% and Mars goes up 5%. Could you talk about why that is,
componenttext: Yes. And secondly, on another topic, you provided information on this crudes in your sweet/sour differential. As I compare the '07 to 2010 period to the 2011 period, Western Canadian Select is down 5% and Mars goes up 5%. Could you talk about why that is, with Mars treading $20 over WTI and WCS, $18 under WTI? It seems like an unusual switch.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. It's primarily driven -- that switch is primarily driven, when we sold our Minnesota refinery last year, St. Paul Park, we've kind of backed off. Not backed off, we use less Canadian crudes this year than we did last year, so t
componenttext: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. It's primarily driven -- that switch is primarily driven, when we sold our Minnesota refinery last year, St. Paul Park, we've kind of backed off. Not backed off, we use less Canadian crudes this year than we did last year, so the big switch there I think you're referring to is just the difference in our refineries.

componenttextpreview: Got you. Maybe a little bit more margin at Garyville as well, huh?
componenttext: Got you. Maybe a little bit more margin at Garyville as well, huh?

componenttext: Correct. Yes, that's correct. Garyville is running -- is a good point, running higher, and so we used a lot of margin to Garyville as well.

componenttext: Great. Any thoughts or plans or capability to include Eagle Ford crudes at Texas City?

componenttext: Yes, absolutely. The Eagle Ford for Texas City is very important to us, obviously. Today, we actually are running as much domestic as we can, and the Eagle Ford has actually gotten into what's called the Gulf Coast light stream that we've maxed out on at Texas City. We're looking at some options that would allow us to back out any foreign crude there, that we run it all because we do expect that we'll run more Eagle Ford in the future, and that's the intent.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Kind of following up on the transpo, let me take a new wrinkle here that I think could maybe limits your future kind of cap line draws of disadvantaged crude. I mean last week, more clarity was provided in the Utica shale potential, the new source of crud
componenttext: Kind of following up on the transpo, let me take a new wrinkle here that I think could maybe limits your future kind of cap line draws of disadvantaged crude. I mean last week, more clarity was provided in the Utica shale potential, the new source of crude production where, in connection with an accelerated rig count activity, Chesapeake called the play Eagle Ford-like. Now, I know MPC is almost 290,000 barrels of your capacity in or bordering Ohio, actually, probably, where you guys are sitting right now. And while it's still early and it appears to be near the Utica fairway, I mean could you provide me with a percentage of your Canton and Catlettsburg runs that are non-price-advantaged feedstock today?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Evan, I think it's a little too early to begin to that level of detail or really that level of competitive knowledge. We only drilled, and I read Chesapeake and some others' discussions on the Utica as well and Marcellus. A few wells have been drilled, lo
componenttext: Evan, I think it's a little too early to begin to that level of detail or really that level of competitive knowledge. We only drilled, and I read Chesapeake and some others' discussions on the Utica as well and Marcellus. A few wells have been drilled, looks promising. And, in fact, as you look at the play, with dry gas to wet gas and then getting it more an oily shale as you go west towards the Ohio border, obviously, it sits right in the fairway for Canton and gives us the ability, due to our transportation system, to take some of that crude if it were to be developed, take some of that down to Catlettsburg.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: That'll be the Ohio River, is that the way the Catlettsburg theoretically at this point?
componenttext: That'll be the Ohio River, is that the way the Catlettsburg theoretically at this point?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, sir. So we have a terminal in Midland, PA, which would give us a way, eventually, to get some crude down there if need be. But it is very early in the exploration side and trying to develop those, but I'd come back and say our 2 refineries are absolu
componenttext: Yes, sir. So we have a terminal in Midland, PA, which would give us a way, eventually, to get some crude down there if need be. But it is very early in the exploration side and trying to develop those, but I'd come back and say our 2 refineries are absolutely setting in the backyard of that play. And I think we are very well positioned, and we will have a tremendous appetite if it can develop for crude source.

componenttext: Okay, that's fair. Also just a quick follow-up. I believe Garyville had some unplanned downtime in July for a week. I mean, could you update us on that and what's going on there, as well as any planned turnarounds through the, really, as far as you want to go? 1Q 2012, I think that's when Garyville were former planned out for January, and I'll leave it at that.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Right. We did have some unplanned downtime just running our hydrocracker and there was a changer that needed to be repaired on the hydrocracker. That kind of straddled the end of the second quarter early into this quarter. It's also been repaired and back up and running. I think we were down the circuit 20 days or so as we went in and made that repair. And so I recall unplanned downtime, it's fixed. It's operating very well back up to its capacity we had been running prior to. So...
