componenttext: The next question comes from Faisel Khan of Citi.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Can you give us a little bit of update on the same-store sales? I know in the quarter, you said you were down 5% year-over-year. I'm just trying to figure out where we're trending. Are we still down 5% into July or we did a little bit better or how are we
componenttext: Can you give us a little bit of update on the same-store sales? I know in the quarter, you said you were down 5% year-over-year. I'm just trying to figure out where we're trending. Are we still down 5% into July or we did a little bit better or how are we looking here until August?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Faisel, I'm really pleased that you asked that question because at the first quarter earnings call, we spoke to our same-store sales and gasoline volume being down. And let me kind of step back and help everyone recall the second quarter of 2010 and how w
componenttext: Faisel, I'm really pleased that you asked that question because at the first quarter earnings call, we spoke to our same-store sales and gasoline volume being down. And let me kind of step back and help everyone recall the second quarter of 2010 and how we led through the balance of the year. And really, as I want everybody to recall, that there was some circumstances outside of our control or anybody else's control that I think really changed a lot of market dynamics of our customers for buying their transportation fuels in the second, third and partially, the fourth quarter of last year. But specifically, the second quarter of 2010, we were up 5% when the market was probably only up about 1% or so. So we picked up a lot of volume that I think was being switched from some other refiners during that period of time. Now this year, we're comparing ourselves on a same-store basis against the same period last year, and we're down, we said, 4%, 4.5% in the second quarter of 2011. So really, we're comparing against a very big increase in the same quarter last year, and now, we hear the market is down this year in the 2% range. So we've still been able to hang on to some of that market share we picked up last year, but clearly, we didn't hang on to all of that. Then in July, we're comparing against last year, we were up about 10% in the month of July on a same-store basis. So we certainly wouldn't expect to hang on to that same amount this year, and we're down this year of almost 4% versus being up 10% last year. So you can see in July, we're still hanging on to a lot of the market share we picked up, but those -- that big circumstance really was outside of our control last year.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, I understand. There's some year-over-year differences. You are looking -- well actually, looking at apples to apples, more looking [indiscernible].
componenttext: Okay, I understand. There's some year-over-year differences. You are looking -- well actually, looking at apples to apples, more looking [indiscernible].

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: There isn't -- and one other key thing that -- I spoke about this a little bit on the first quarter call, was we calculate approximately 1% drop just in demand because of weather that was across the entire Mid-Continent here in the second quarter. Now we
componenttext: There isn't -- and one other key thing that -- I spoke about this a little bit on the first quarter call, was we calculate approximately 1% drop just in demand because of weather that was across the entire Mid-Continent here in the second quarter. Now we had very, very heavy rains in May and then again in different parts of June. So -- and that just doesn't come back. That's probably just a 1% decline in this overall demand.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess excluding all these sort of comparison issues, where would you say we were for July in terms of real demand growth across your system? If you normalize for all these issues, did you see demand actually go down again for general gasoline d
componenttext: Okay. So I guess excluding all these sort of comparison issues, where would you say we were for July in terms of real demand growth across your system? If you normalize for all these issues, did you see demand actually go down again for general gasoline demand in your overall territories or were they kind of flat?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: I would say gasoline demand, what has happened is if we compare same period this year versus same period last year, we're up about $0.85 a gallon in retail price, about $2.69 last year in the second quarter, $3.74 this year. Month-to-date, we're about $3.
componenttext: I would say gasoline demand, what has happened is if we compare same period this year versus same period last year, we're up about $0.85 a gallon in retail price, about $2.69 last year in the second quarter, $3.74 this year. Month-to-date, we're about $3.72. So I'd say gasoline price has, would have a bigger effect on the overall demand, but the kind of -- put a barometer on it, I would say, Faisel, we're probably down in the 2% to 3% range in overall gasoline demand.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, understood. And then one question. On the -- I heard you guys, your earlier comments on the derivatives, on the derivative gain, is that a cash gain or is there any mark-to-market impact in those numbers?
componenttext: Okay, understood. And then one question. On the -- I heard you guys, your earlier comments on the derivatives, on the derivative gain, is that a cash gain or is there any mark-to-market impact in those numbers?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. We mark to market everything. Every month, every quarter, we mark to market all of our derivative activity, but most of our derivative activity is only a month or 2 out. So for the most part, it is cash. Very little of that $23
componenttext: Yes, this is Garry Peiffer. We mark to market everything. Every month, every quarter, we mark to market all of our derivative activity, but most of our derivative activity is only a month or 2 out. So for the most part, it is cash. Very little of that $234 million gain relates to activities that'll come through in the next month or so, so the majority -- almost all of that $234 million was cash that, from a derivative standpoint, we benefited from in the second quarter or that was offsetting negative effects from the commodity side as well. So it was basically cash for cash in the second quarter with very little carryover effect beyond the second quarter.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I understand the use of derivatives for your foreign crude acquisition. But you also talked about in your press release, seasonal inventory price exposure. I guess how much of that $235 million is related to kind of managing your inventory?
componenttext: Okay. And I understand the use of derivatives for your foreign crude acquisition. But you also talked about in your press release, seasonal inventory price exposure. I guess how much of that $235 million is related to kind of managing your inventory?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: It was, about $84 million of that $234 million was inventory-related.
componenttext: It was, about $84 million of that $234 million was inventory-related.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, That makes sense.
componenttext: Okay, That makes sense.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I think as you might've heard from Don, Don's discussion when we looked at cash, we have pretty substantial increases in inventories in the second quarter. So we've always taken the approach, much like on the crude acquisition, that we're trying to ma
componenttext: And I think as you might've heard from Don, Don's discussion when we looked at cash, we have pretty substantial increases in inventories in the second quarter. So we've always taken the approach, much like on the crude acquisition, that we're trying to make our money on the crack, not on changes in the prices of the absolute price so any seasonal changes we have in inventories, the physical inventories, we go shorten and hedges that as well.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Okay. So we should see that inventory draw kind of diverse itself into third, fourth quarter?

componenttext: Well, I wouldn't -- to a certain degree, the cash effect or the P&L effect has already been reflected in the, for the most part during the quarter.

componenttext: But the working capital effect? Because that was...

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the Detroit refinery upgrade. You've talked about it being completed in the second half of next year. And I'm just wondering, with the lag time to receive the Canadian oil at the refinery, when do you anticipate this project starting to
componenttext: Just a question on the Detroit refinery upgrade. You've talked about it being completed in the second half of next year. And I'm just wondering, with the lag time to receive the Canadian oil at the refinery, when do you anticipate this project starting to contribute to earnings?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Jacques, we're about 63% complete as we've -- as I've stated earlier, and this is the most important construction season that we're in. And I'll be able to give you -- by the time we're together in November and have our big Analyst Meeting, I think
componenttext: Well, Jacques, we're about 63% complete as we've -- as I've stated earlier, and this is the most important construction season that we're in. And I'll be able to give you -- by the time we're together in November and have our big Analyst Meeting, I think we'll be able to give you a more detailed timeline. Because as I've also said earlier, once we complete the actual construction, then we will need to tie in some of the process units and have a turnaround in that facility. But we'll weigh it all out in more detail when we get together in November, and we really lock in our schedule at that time.

componenttext: Okay, in the first quarter of 2011, we had a loss of $57 million. And just by way of reference, in the second quarter of last year, we had a gain of $74 million.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011

componenttext: Gary, you covered quite a bit of detail in Doug Terreson's first question on Garyville, for its nameplate capacity. I was curious though on the cost side of things. As I understand it, there was, I guess, a target to reduce cost by about 20%. And I was curious if you can give us a status update there.

componenttext: Yes, Blake, and we believe that we're very comfortable that we are right in line with the design we had and in reducing our overall fixed cost, so right in line with our plan.

componenttext: And, Gary, can you remind me the timeframe of when that's supposed to be accomplished? Or is there one?

componenttext: We believe we're already there.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Secondly, you mentioned organic projects, and I'm just curious, now that the company's been split, obviously, you're not competing for capital with the upstream. Could you give us a sense of maybe some of the smaller organic projects that may
componenttext: Okay. Great. Secondly, you mentioned organic projects, and I'm just curious, now that the company's been split, obviously, you're not competing for capital with the upstream. Could you give us a sense of maybe some of the smaller organic projects that maybe are on the table, that could make their way into the budget?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I probably would be remiss, Blake, if I didn't really say thank you to Clarence Cazalot for all the tremendous capital that he allowed us to invest in the downstream. We were a contrary. We've got the most companies the investor liked more in our
componenttext: Yes, and I probably would be remiss, Blake, if I didn't really say thank you to Clarence Cazalot for all the tremendous capital that he allowed us to invest in the downstream. We were a contrary. We've got the most companies the investor liked more in our downstream versus others. But I wouldn't say that -- I'd never go on and say that we're starved for capital. I thought we had plenty of capital to say grace over. But with some things that we have found, it's been very clear that Garyville is operating significantly above its design capacity, when that happens, then you're producing a lot more product in certain steps of the process units. Therefore, that you might need some room for in -- as you run those process units, which draws me back to the de-bottlenecking. So not big projects, but we think some very significant rates of return-type projects that we will see down the road. But again, I don't believe that we were ever starved for capital.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I would agree. I didn't mean to insinuate that. I just wanted to confirm that there were some smaller projects that could easily make their way on the books and have a decent rate of return associated with them, so...
componenttext: No, I would agree. I didn't mean to insinuate that. I just wanted to confirm that there were some smaller projects that could easily make their way on the books and have a decent rate of return associated with them, so...

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I understand that and that's a very good question. And it's most set at Garyville, we're already seeing a few things. And in Detroit, as what we have learned to the Garyville project, already the design that is totally engineered at Garyville and seei
componenttext: No, I understand that and that's a very good question. And it's most set at Garyville, we're already seeing a few things. And in Detroit, as what we have learned to the Garyville project, already the design that is totally engineered at Garyville and seeing how some of the equipment is operating at Garyville, that we're probably going to have some upside organically there also.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ann Kohler of CRT Capital Group.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ann Kohler of CRT Capital Group.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First, going back to growth of the Speedway market, can you just provide a little bit more color in terms of what the criteria that you look for when you look for retail sites? And also, sort of kind of what level you're looking to
componenttext: A couple of questions. First, going back to growth of the Speedway market, can you just provide a little bit more color in terms of what the criteria that you look for when you look for retail sites? And also, sort of kind of what level you're looking to get to in terms of the amount of throughput that you have that goes through those sites, where you are currently and where you would like to get to in any timeframe in terms of which you would like to achieve that objective?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Right, Ann. Here in the Midwest, 8 or 9 states that Speedway operates, we're very pleased with the tremendous integration we have between the gasoline volume and the merchandise sales. But what we're talking about is wanting to branch out and be able to m
componenttext: Right, Ann. Here in the Midwest, 8 or 9 states that Speedway operates, we're very pleased with the tremendous integration we have between the gasoline volume and the merchandise sales. But what we're talking about is wanting to branch out and be able to move closer to either the colonial or plantation system, where we can deliver Garyville barrels through our proprietary terminal system that we already have. We think that gives us a very good fit and now we can capture the entire supply chain. So in and around the Midwest where we already operate, we will continue to want to fill out some of our markets where there are new interstate locations or new subdivisions being built, so on and so forth. But as we go, as we move into the Southeast -- and you'll recall, we used to be in a number of states in the Southeast, but we didn't have very strong market share that, nor did we have the density to be able to really justify any big marketing campaigns. So as we look going into the Southeast, we will want to be closer to our marketing and terminal systems.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just finally, you mentioned that the capitalized interest that you had this year, I would assume that you would have a similar level, maybe even higher, next year as well as you finish up the Detroit project?
componenttext: Great. And then just finally, you mentioned that the capitalized interest that you had this year, I would assume that you would have a similar level, maybe even higher, next year as well as you finish up the Detroit project?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes. We -- I guess our interest cost would be roughly, I want to say, $40 million a quarter based upon our $3.3 billion of debt. And I would anticipate that capitalized interest will consume a major portion of that interest cost on a quarterly basis, Ann.
componenttext: Yes. We -- I guess our interest cost would be roughly, I want to say, $40 million a quarter based upon our $3.3 billion of debt. And I would anticipate that capitalized interest will consume a major portion of that interest cost on a quarterly basis, Ann.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-on from your comments on Brent and speculative lengths. I mean if you believe that the, I guess, speculators are pushing up Brent relative to WTI, would you consider locking it in because obviously, that would underpin some of the cash flow,
componenttext: Just a follow-on from your comments on Brent and speculative lengths. I mean if you believe that the, I guess, speculators are pushing up Brent relative to WTI, would you consider locking it in because obviously, that would underpin some of the cash flow, CapEx, inorganic CapEx and perhaps pay higher dividends?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Ed, historically, our shareholders have not been too amused by when we lock things in, either when we win or we lose, when we lock things in. So I would say, at this time, that would not be our plan.
componenttext: Well, Ed, historically, our shareholders have not been too amused by when we lock things in, either when we win or we lose, when we lock things in. So I would say, at this time, that would not be our plan.

componenttext: Our last question is a follow-up question from Paul Cheng of Barclays Capital.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Gary, in Robinson and Catlettsburg, do we have any low-cost opportunity for some small capacity expansion? Or is that those 2 are pretty much quite fit and any expense in there would be very costly?
componenttext: Gary, in Robinson and Catlettsburg, do we have any low-cost opportunity for some small capacity expansion? Or is that those 2 are pretty much quite fit and any expense in there would be very costly?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Garry Peiffer. Nothing significant at this time. We're looking primarily at Robinson and all plants, kind of the lag question of ways to run more of the Mid-Continent crude. So I would say, given the demand outlook in the Midwest in particul
componenttext: Paul, this is Garry Peiffer. Nothing significant at this time. We're looking primarily at Robinson and all plants, kind of the lag question of ways to run more of the Mid-Continent crude. So I would say, given the demand outlook in the Midwest in particular, our focus is more on lowering our feedstock cost more than increasing capacity at this time.

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: And how about -- I think you get a new permit to potentially have Garyville up to more than 500,000 barrels per day. Have you had any cost estimate how much it may take to expand in that fashion?
componenttext: And how about -- I think you get a new permit to potentially have Garyville up to more than 500,000 barrels per day. Have you had any cost estimate how much it may take to expand in that fashion?

headline: Marathon Petroleum Corporation, Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Garry Peiffer again, Paul. No, not at this point. As I think we've said, I think that permit is good for 2 years. And we have to -- and that's a stream day rate as well that we're talking about, the 270, so we wouldn't expect that it'd have a sust
componenttext: This is Garry Peiffer again, Paul. No, not at this point. As I think we've said, I think that permit is good for 2 years. And we have to -- and that's a stream day rate as well that we're talking about, the 270, so we wouldn't expect that it'd have a sustainable level. So that's what we're going through now. We're going to the testing and see what we can do with the new units and making sure that we can do it safely and we can sustain those rates. So I guess that's kind of definitely a work in progress at Garyville at the moment.
